title: Governing black soils for food and climate security
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69018-7Black soils feed the world yet remain undervalued in food and climate governance frameworks. A policy package, including global monitoring as public infrastructure, co-designed and place-based solutions based on tailored tools, planning that fits land and people, mobilizing alliance with finance and force, and mainstreaming black soils in global pacts, can contribute to improving land quality and stabilize yields where it matters most.

title: Ectopic cambia in wisteria vines are associated with the expression of conserved KNOX genes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68669-wHere, using anatomy, transcriptomics, and functional assays, the authors reveal how Japanese wisteria climb using an unusual vascular architecture. Ectopic cambia arise from cortical cells and repurpose conserved cambium regulators, including KNOX genes.

title: Growth of rhombohedral-stacked single-crystal WS<sub>2</sub>/MoS<sub>2</sub> vertical heterostructures
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68935-xRhombohedral-stacked structures formed by 2D semiconductors are characterized by emerging physical properties, but their bottom-up growth remains challenging. Here, the authors report a chemical vapour deposition method to grow cm-scale rhombohedral-stacked WS2/MoS2 crystals with ferroelectric properties.

title: Neglected tropical diseases: the need for an integrated approach to achieve the 2030 roadmap
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69020-zNeglected tropical diseases are ancient maladies that continue to disproportionately affect more than one billion of the world’s poorest people. In 2021, as part of its strategy to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals, the World Health Organization renewed its commitment to end their neglect by 2030. On World Neglected Tropical Diseases Day 2026, we discuss the need for an integrated approach to overcome the “last mile” barriers to achieving their eradication and elimination.

title: Supercharging-enhanced nDIA-MS enables global profiling of drug-induced proteome solubility shifts
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69025-8Protein function is governed by more than abundance alone. Here, the authors introduce a supercharging-enhanced nDIA-MS workflow to map drug-induced solubility changes across the proteome, enabling high-throughput analysis of protein state transitions.

title: TMEM63 proteins act as mechanically activated cholesterol modulated lipid scramblases contributing to membrane mechano-resilience
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68919-xOSCA/TMEM63 proteins act as both ion channels and mechanically activated lipid scramblases. They translocate lipids through open pores, with cholesterol inhibiting scrambling, aiding membrane remodeling and cell resilience under mechanical stress.

title: Geoethics: The Role of Geoscientists in Shaping a Responsible Future
authors: Silvia Peppoloni and Giuseppe Di Capua
summary:
Geoethics is an evolving interdisciplinary field that provides ethical guidance for how humanity interacts with the Earth system. Originating in professional geoscience ethics, it has expanded to include the ethical, social, and cultural aspects of geoscientific practice. Today, it is proposed as a foundation for developing a global ethics. This review traces the evolution of geoethics through key milestones, such as international organizations and foundational documents, and outlines its core principles. It also highlights the wide-ranging applicability of geoethics across diverse and pressing issues. The practical relevance of geoethics extends to fields such as disaster risk reduction, geo-resource management, the protection of geodiversity and geoheritage, geoeducation, and geoscience communication. Geoethics also provides ethical reflections in emerging and controversial domains, including deep-sea mining and the use of artificial intelligence in geosciences. By fostering ethical awareness, responsibility, and reflexivity in geoscientific practice, geoethics contributes to shaping a more sustainable, inclusive, and just future.
  • ▪  Geoethics integrates geoscience, ethics, and society to guide responsible human-Earth interactions.
  • ▪  It provides a framework for addressing global challenges such as climate change and resource management.
  • ▪  Geoethics promotes scientific integrity, sustainability, and planetary stewardship across disciplines.
  • ▪  Its principles foster ethical awareness, shaping policy, education, and societal engagement worldwide.
source: Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences: Most Recent Articles

title: The Impact of Volcanic Eruptions on Tropical Hydroclimate
authors: Roberta D’Agostino, Shih-Wei Fang, Myriam Khodri, Francesco S.R. Pausata, Ernesto Tejedor, Claudia Timmreck and Davide Zanchettin
summary:
Volcanic eruptions exert a profound influence on tropical hydroclimate, including interannual variability associated with the El Niño–Southern Oscillation. This review synthesizes recent advances in understanding these impacts through an energy framework that links radiative forcing to shifts in the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) and global monsoon systems. While global responses are robust in climate models, regional expressions remain uncertain due to biases and limitations in both simulations and paleoclimate reconstructions. Nonetheless, consistent patterns emerge—such as ITCZ displacement and reduced monsoon precipitation—that align with energetic theory, offering a physically grounded explanation for observed hydroclimatic anomalies following eruptions. This framework also provides a basis for estimating potential hydroclimate impacts of future volcanic events.
  • ▪  Volcanic eruptions strongly influence tropical hydroclimate, but the mechanisms linking radiative forcing to large-scale responses are not fully understood.
  • ▪  We assess evidence from climate models and paleoclimate reconstructions, noting robust global responses but regional differences due to model biases and data limitations.
  • ▪  The energy framework provides a physically based foundation for anticipating tropical hydroclimate responses to future volcanic eruptions.
  • ▪  Consistent patterns emerge such as ITCZ shifts and weakened monsoons, explained by energy theory and underpinned by observed posteruption climate anomalies.
source: Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences: Most Recent Articles

summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10007-zThe fluorooxoborate crystal NH4B4O6F shows promise as a nonlinear optical material for vacuum ultraviolet light sources through second-harmonic generation, demonstrating record output energy and efficiency resulting from optimized arrangements of fluorine-based units creating asymmetric sublattices.

title: Psychedelics elicit their effects by 5-HT<sub>2A</sub> receptor-mediated G<sub>i</sub> signalling
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10061-7Psychedelics and their non-hallucinogenic analogues were compared, revealing that serotonin 2A receptor (5-HT2AR)-mediated Gi signalling is essential for hallucinogenic effect, with the functional mechanisms underlying this providing insights for designing therapeutic drugs without hallucinogenic effects.

title: Limit of atomic-resolution-tomography reconstruction of amorphous nanoparticles
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09924-wA simulation approach is used to ascertain the limitations on the structural and chemical information that atomic-resolution electron tomography can determine from noisy electron images.

title: Optofluidic three-dimensional microfabrication and nanofabrication
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10033-xA strategy compatible with a broad range of materials by precisely manipulating optofluidic interactions within a confined 3D space to control the assembly of colloidal microparticles/nanoparticles is demonstrated, enabling the precise manufacture of complex microstructures/nanostructures.

title: Ferromagnet-like binary switching of a Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnet
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10019-9CrPS4, a 2D van der Waals A-type antiferromagnet, is shown to exhibit ideal characteristics of Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnets, such as ferromagnet-like binary switching rather than layer-by-layer flipping as in other 2D A-type antiferromagnets.

title: The Ocean Equity Index
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09976-yThe Ocean Equity Index provides a systematic, twelve-criteria framework to assess and improve equity in ocean initiatives, projects and policies, producing structured data that guide evidence-based decisions and support more equitable outcomes for coastal communities and ecosystems.

title: A flexible digital compute-in-memory chip for edge intelligence
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09931-xA flexible digital artificial intelligence chip with a compute-in-memory architecture is fabricated using a commercial low-temperature polycrystalline silicon thin-film transistor process and shows high accuracy in human daily activity monitoring using multimodal physiological signals.

title: Optical control over topological Chern number in moiré materials
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09851-wOptical spin orientation of itinerant ferromagnets in twisted MoTe2 homobilayers is demonstrated, enabling control of topological Chern numbers with circularly polarized light.

title: Disentangling multiple gas kinematic drivers in the Perseus galaxy cluster
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10017-xKinematic measurements of the Perseus galaxy cluster reveal two drivers of gas motions: a small-scale driver in the inner core associated with black-hole feedback and a large-scale driver in the outer core powered by mergers.

title: Holistic motor control of zebra finch song syllable sequences
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10069-zA cortical premotor network in HVC, once initiated, can sustain and regulate the sequential production of zebra finch song syllables without major extrinsic inputs.

title: A benchmark of expert-level academic questions to assess AI capabilities
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09962-4Humanity’s Last Exam, a multi-modal benchmark at the frontier of human knowledge, is designed to be an expert-level closed-ended academic benchmark with broad subject coverage.

title: GlycoRNA complexed with heparan sulfate regulates VEGF-A signalling
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10052-8Heparan sulfate proteoglycans facilitate the assembly of clusters of glycoRNAs and cell surface RNA-binding proteins, which negatively modulate VEGF-A signalling and angiogenesis.

title: Pre-assembly of biomolecular condensate seeds drives RSV replication
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10071-5Viral ribonucleoprotein–viral protein networks form pre-replication centres that nucleate viral factories and drive respiratory syncytial virus replication.

title: Structures of Ostα/β reveal a unique fold and bile acid transport mechanism
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10029-7Cryogenic electron microscopy structures of human Ostα/β uncover a unique transport pathway featuring two substrate-binding sites connected by an amphipathic helix-gated conduit, and electrophysiological studies demonstrate voltage-sensitive, bidirectional transport, showing its efflux role in vivo.

title: Observation of a superfluid-to-insulator transition of bilayer excitons
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09986-wTransition of superfluid to insulator is observed in the layer-imbalanced regime of bilayer magnetoexcitons.

title: Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10048-4Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet is demonstrated in twisted molybdenum ditelluride bilayers using continuous-wave circularly polarized light, paving the way for dissipationless spintronics and quantized Chern junction devices.

title: Vagal blood volume receptors compensate for haemorrhage and posture change
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10010-4A vagal reflex to blood volume changes in the heart involves PIEZO2 and helps to stabilize blood pressure in an upright posture and after blood loss.

title: Structure and mechanism of the human bile acid transporter OSTα–OSTβ
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09934-8Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the bile acid transporter OSTα–OSTβ, which has a key role in bile acid homeostasis, provide insight into its distinct architecture and mechanism of substrate translocation.

title: Act now to clean up air
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00108-8New regulations are needed to deal with increasing environmental threats to lung health.

title: Chill out: freezing temperatures produced by letting a stressed alloy relax
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00030-zA device has been built that relies on a solid-state phenomenon called the elastocaloric effect to produce cooling to temperatures below 0 °C, lower than existing room-temperature elastocaloric cooling systems are able to achieve. The innovation demonstrates that elastocaloric technology could offer an alternative to conventional freezing systems that use volatile greenhouse gases.

title: Deep-sea robots will search for source of mysterious ‘dark oxygen’
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00266-9Scientists have launched a fresh effort to find out what could be producing oxygen at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Exposome studies can improve lung health
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00106-wA new set of analytical tools will help researchers to understand the lifelong effects of air pollution.

title: AI chatbots are infiltrating social-science surveys — and getting better at avoiding detection
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00221-8A researcher has created a chatbot that is indistinguishable from human participants in online surveys. Some researchers fear that a workhorse of social science is now under threat.

title: A step towards building miniature human livers
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04012-5Recapitulating the complexity of human organs in vitro would accelerate drug discovery and enable personalized treatments. By combining different types of liver cell from donor tissues, in vitro models of a liver region that mirror some of the organ’s main structures and functions can be assembled, getting closer to reproducing mini livers in vitro.

title: Scraps of viral DNA in biobank samples reveal secrets of Epstein–Barr virus
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00038-5Viral DNA that is usually dismissed when sequencing the human genome could help to uncover useful information about complex diseases.

title: Alternative explanation for how celestial objects generate large-scale magnetic fields
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00026-9Numerical simulations provide a mechanism that explains how celestial objects such as stars and galaxies can generate ordered, macroscopic magnetic fields. The mechanism arises from turbulence — chaotic changes in the pressure and velocity of fluid — and avoids a physical effect that hinders other proposed systems from explaining observed ordered fields.

title: Funding cuts could put research into emerging threats to lung health at risk
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00104-yWildfire smoke, spore-spread fungal diseases and microplastic are all on the rise, even as the US government slashes support for respiratory research and policy.

title: Treatments for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis are on the horizon
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00109-7The life-threatening disease affects millions of people, but has no effective therapy. Drugs under development could target the condition before fibrosis becomes established.

title: Six highlights from lung-health research
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00111-zFibrosis survival, long COVID’s lasting toll and other highlights from lung studies.

title: Expert-level test is a head-scratcher for AI
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04098-xConventional benchmarks are becoming less effective at assessing AI performance, but a multi-disciplinary test has set AI systems a fresh challenge.

title: Wikipedia is needed now more than ever, 25 years on
summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00074-1The online encyclopedia is an antidote to an increasingly poisoned information ecosystem. Researchers should help to nourish it.

summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00237-0‘Exercise snacks’ and other forms of everyday movement can greatly reduce the risk of heart disease and death.

summary: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00126-6Presentation matters.

title: Estimation of hydrofluorocarbon emissions from China and other non-Annex I countries
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01908-9Non-Annex I countries—mostly developing countries under the UN climate framework—excluding China accounted for approximately 61% of hydrofluorocarbon emission growth during 2011–2020, while China’s emissions have been overestimated since 2017, according to atmospheric observational data and inverse modelling.

title: Leveraging glucan-induced trained immunity for the epigenetic and metabolic rewiring of macrophages to enhance colorectal cancer vaccine response
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68466-5Beta-glucan is an inducer of trained immunity, an epigenetic and metabolic reprogramming of the innate immune cells conferring immunological memory. Here the authors show that glucan-induced trained immunity enhances response to a cancer vaccine platform in colorectal cancer models, by inducing epigenetic and metabolic rewiring of macrophages that promotes an NK-cDC1 axis boosting anti-tumor immunity.

title: A universal all-dry microfabrication method for sensitive electronic materials via an inorganic molecular lithographic mediator
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68593-zConventional organic polymeric resists and chemical solutions used in microlithographic techniques can damage sensitive materials. Here, the authors report the application of inorganic selenium molecules as a lithographic mediator and encapsulation layer during the processing of various sensitive materials, such as perovskites and black phosphorus.

title: The climate opportunities and risks of contrail avoidance
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68784-8This study shows that contrail avoidance can recover 9% of the global temperature budget by 2050. For every year of delay, the recoverable warming will diminish by 0.6%. This makes inaction (not fuel penalties) the most significant climate risk associated with avoidance.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a smart pillbox intervention for adherence to oral HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68970-8A recent randomised controlled trial demonstrated effectiveness of a smart pillbox for oral HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis adherence in men who have sex with men in China. Here, the authors show that the intervention is cost effective, with greater benefits for more socially vulnerable groups.

title: A comprehensive tandem repeat catalog of the human genome
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66153-5Current human tandem repeat catalogs are derived from short-read sequencing data, thus limiting the size range and sequence complexity of captured genotypes. Here the authors generate a comprehensive catalog de novo using long-read sequencing data.

title: Coherent Ising machine based on polarization symmetry breaking in a driven Kerr resonator
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68794-6Coherent Ising machines suffer from stringent phase stabilization requirements. Here, authors provide a proof-of-concept demonstration of an optical coherent Ising machine, where spins are encoded in the polarization of light and can be accessed via intensity measurements, thereby lifting the limitations related to phase stabilization.

title: Lipid Nanoparticle Database towards structure-function modeling and data-driven design for nucleic acid delivery
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68818-1This study introduces the Lipid Nanoparticle Database (LNPDB) and web tool that consolidates lipid nanoparticle structure-function data. LNPDB facilitates molecular dynamics and deep learning approaches to advance data-driven design for nucleic acid delivery.

title: Reactivation of basement faults by deep fluids during the 2017 Changdao earthquake swarm, Eastern China
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03228-1A distinctive migration pattern consistent with fluid pressure diffusion is identified within a high-resolution earthquake catalogue of the 2017 Changdao swarm and suggests a fault-valve mechanism driven by overpressure CO2-rich fluids was responsible.

title: Glacially derived iron is more bioavailable to Antarctic phytoplankton than other sources
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03092-5Compared to iron from groundwater, iron fertilization from glacial meltwater doubles primary production in low chlorophyll waters around South Georgia, according to analysis of in-situ experiments from the South Atlantic.

title: What were the first animals? The fierce sponge–jelly battle that just won’t end
summary: Nature, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00238-zFor almost two decades, scientists have debated whether sponges or comb jellies are the first animal lineage. Now some are calling for a more harmonious approach.

title: How to eat well and within Earth’s limits
summary: Nature, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00236-1Dietary change, supported by bold policies, is essential for a sustainable planet.

title: Sensors are transforming the world — work together to maximize their benefits
summary: Nature, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00234-3To get the most out of the sensing revolution, different disciplines need to be on the same wavelength. This is a priority for the Nature Portfolio’s newest journal, Nature Sensors.

title: Should professors be forced to retire?
summary: Nature, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00055-4Some universities are implementing a mandatory retirement age for academics. Will it help young researchers to get permanent positions?

title: Still working at 107: supercentenarian study probes genetics of extreme longevity
summary: Nature, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00256-xScientists seek to understand the factors that have allowed people in Brazil to reach their 100th or even 110th birthdays despite facing adversities.

title: Daily briefing: Blister beetles hoodwink bees with floral smells
summary: Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00271-yBeetle larvae are the first animal known to imitate the scent of a flower. Plus, a proposal for a new north-star number for climate progress and why Greenland is a unique hotspot for research.

title: Landfalling tropical cyclones accelerate due to land–sea thermal and roughness contrasts
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01891-1Landfalling tropical cyclones generally accelerate as they approach coastlines due to changes in surface roughness and thermal properties, according to numerical modelling simulations and global observations.

title: Ultrafast dynamic stark shift of an exciton-polariton condensate
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68703-xUltrafast shaping of exciton-polariton condensates enables applications for classical and quantum logic devices and provides insights into the physics of nonequilibrium quantum condensates in solid-state. Here, the authors demonstrate ultrafast and reversible dynamic Stark modulation of a semiconductor exciton-polariton quantum condensate.

title: Author Correction: A streamlined base editor engineering strategy to reduce bystander editing
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68616-9Author Correction: A streamlined base editor engineering strategy to reduce bystander editing

title: The Drosophila proventriculus lacks stem cells but compensates for age-related cell loss via endoreplication-mediated cell growth
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68876-5This study demonstrates that the Drosophila proventriculus, the structure at the anterior of gut that synthesizes the peritrophic membrane, lacks stem cells but undergoes continual endocycling to compensate for cells loss during aging or damage.

title: Structural basis and pathological implications of the dimeric OS9-SEL1L-HRD1 ERAD Core Complex
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68777-7Cells rely on ER-associated degradation (ERAD) to eliminate misfolded proteins. Here, the authors report the cryo-EM structure of the mammalian SEL1L-HRD1 ERAD core complex, revealing a dimeric architecture and explaining how disease-linked mutations disrupt protein quality control.

title: Ion diffusion overestimates figures of merit in polymeric mixed conductors
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67546-2There is a challenge of overestimation in figures of merit for organic electrochemical transistors due to a kink in the transistor current. Here, the authors investigate the origin of the kink and identify the charge transport phenomena that is impacted.

title: Topological robustness of classical and quantum optical skyrmions in atmospheric turbulence
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68751-3Optical skyrmions can be generated in free space, but topologically protected information transfer requires skyrmions to be stable upon propagation through complex media. Here, authors demonstrate the topological resilience of classical and quantum optical skyrmions transmitted through experimentally simulated atmospheric turbulence.

title: Synthesis of poly(ester disulfide)s from S<sub>8</sub>-involved step-growth addition polymerization at ambient temperature
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68963-7The synthesis of high molecular weight poly(disulfide)s typically requires harsh conditions or the complex cyclic disulfide monomers. Here, the authors report a mild, room-temperature multicomponent polymerisation using elemental sulfur to yield high molecular weight poly(ester disulfide)s

title: Abiotic sugar enantiomers in the CI carbonaceous chondrite Orgueil
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68709-5A joint analysis of sugars and amino acids in the Orgueil meteorite, a proxy for asteroids Bennu and Ryugu, reveals multiple biologically relevant sugars, including ribose, supporting efficient sugar formation in space and a richer prebiotic delivery to early Earth.

title: Major Baltic Inflows do not have long-lasting consequences for 20<sup>th</sup>-century hypoxia in the central Baltic Sea
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03245-0The 1951 Major Baltic Inflow did not impact stratification or hypoxia in the Baltic Sea over long timescales, according to analyses of simulations using a hydrodynamical-ecosystem numerical model.

title: An outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 could impact the dairy cattle sector and the broader economy in the United States
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03153-9In the United States, the avian influenza outbreak in dairy cattle could impact the economy and public health, with estimated losses to global domestic product of 0.9 percent and dairy output losses of up to 20 percent, according to a simulation of a computable general equilibrium model.

title: Mycorrhizal-specific responses of rhizosphere soil properties and fine-root traits to polystyrene microplastic addition in a temperate mixed forest
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03237-0After microplastic addition, rhizosphere nitrogen increased but phosphorus decreased in ectomycorrhizal trees, while arbuscular mycorrhizal trees showed an opposite trend of lower nitrogen and higher phosphorus in rhizosphere soil, based on a field study in Changbai Mountain Nature Reserve, China.

title: Indigenous Peoples and local communities as agents of transformative change for sustainability
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03098-zEquitable, just, and effective transformative change for sustainability requires diverse actors and knowledge systems. Indigenous Peoples and local communities play critical roles in advancing strategies and pathways that halt biodiversity loss and reverse nature’s decline.

title: Slope lineae as potential indicators of recent volatile loss on Mercury
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 27 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03146-8A comprehensive mapping approach using MESSENGER data finds that slope lineae on Mercury are preferentially oriented towards the equator on the sun-facing slopes of impact craters, suggesting they form through volatile release due to insolation

title: Climate change risk index and municipal bond disclosures of United States drinking water utilities
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03044-z67 million customers across the US rely on drinking water utilities that face higher climate risk than accounted for, which exposes major gaps in climate adaptation and resilience planning, suggests an assessment of vulnerability, exposure, and hazards across 1,455 municipal utilities.

title: Recent giant detachment of a glacier on the Tibetan plateau provoked by its frozen tongue
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03125-zMassively increased ice speeds in combination with a stable terminus position led to a giant ice detachment (~40 million cubic meters) from a Tibetan glacier in November 2022, which ranks among the largest recorded ice avalanches, according to a study based on satellite imagery and seismic data.

summary: Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00208-5A supercooled microscopic ferromagnet proves the existence of gyroscopic magnetic behaviour that has been long sought by physicists.

title: Audio long read: ‘I rarely get outside’ — scientists ditch fieldwork in the age of AI
summary: Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00255-yIn the wake of new computer-based methods, some ecologists fear their field is losing touch with nature.

title: Why do women like me get diagnosed with ADHD late?
summary: Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00260-1Emily Bates was diagnosed with ADHD at the age of 34. She explores how the condition presents in women and why so many are diagnosed later in life.

summary: Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00245-0An exploration of how writing systems, from ancient Chinese characters to modern alphabets, shape language, and whether users of ChatGPT can be said to be authors at all.

title: As we breach 1.5 °C, we must replace temperature limits with clean-energy targets
summary: Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00246-zActionable goals are needed to guide the world towards what needs to happen most quickly: shifting economies to clean energy sources.

title: Exceeding 1.5 °C requires rethinking accountability in climate policy
summary: Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00247-yA scientific foundation is required to establish nations’ responsibilities in a hotter ‘overshoot’ world.

title: Daily briefing: Why cancer might protect against Alzheimer’s disease
summary: Nature, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00257-wA protein made by cancer cells seems to break down the hallmark plaques of Alzheimer’s disease. Plus, our breath might reveal what’s going on in our gut and the controversy surrounding a US-funded hepatitis B vaccine trial in Guinea-Bissau.

title: Daily briefing: Largest ever ‘superposition’ pushes quantum boundary
summary: Nature, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00242-3Physicists have shown that a quantum object can be at least as big as a cluster of 7,000 sodium atoms. Plus, the oldest-known cave art in the world and why girls are starting puberty earlier than ever.

title: Long-period microseismicity reveals cryptic earthquake-triggered fluid activity can facilitate caldera eruptions
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68645-4A M5 earthquake triggered the 2018 Sierra Negra eruption after 10 hours. Subsequent microseismicity revealed a cryptic fluid phase facilitated magma intrusion, highlighting that cascading processes are potentially essential for eruption initiations.

title: Carbon sequestration for geological negative emissions of the shale gas value chain in China
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68829-yChina’s shale gas value chain can achieve net-negative carbon emissions through geological sequestration, offering a viable pathway for large-scale decarbonization in the energy sector.

title: Quality of life and multiple long-term conditions in Southeast Asia: a systematic review and meta-analysis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68197-zPeople living with multiple long-term conditions often experience reduced quality of life, but evidence from Southeast Asia is fragmented. Here the authors show that commonly used tools indicate moderately reduced yet generally good quality of life, highlighting the need for context-sensitive measurement approaches.

title: National climate action can ameliorate, perpetuate, or exacerbate international air pollution inequalities
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68827-0Climate action could avoid over 1 million deaths globally from air pollution in 2040. However, it is suggested that cooperation is needed between developed and developing nations to ensure that disparities in air pollution are not perpetuated in the future.

title: A DNA-based nanodevice senses purinergic signaling and drives an immune switch for resolving inflammation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68879-2Purinergic signalling dysregulation can drive inflammatory disorders, but effective targeted therapy is still lacking. Here, authors develop a smart DNA origami nanodevice that can precisely sense and metabolize high levels of extracellular ATP, thereby fine-tuning purinergic signalling and immune homeostasis.

title: Single-crystalline Ba<sub>x</sub>Sr<sub>1-x</sub>TaO<sub>2</sub>N solid-solution photocatalyst with low defect concentrations for solar-driven water splitting
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68848-9Photocatalytic water splitting using a single particulate photocatalyst is a cost-efficient approach for sustainable hydrogen production. Here, the authors report a nanoscale BaxSr1-xTaO2N solid-solution photocatalyst exhibits an apparent quantum efficiency of 13.5% for H2 evolution at 420 nm.

title: Substantially lower estimates in China’s offshore wind potential using farm-scale spatial modeling and wake effects
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68655-2The study evaluates China’s offshore wind potential using farm-scale modeling, revealing lower potential than previous estimates. title: Electrical control of the metal-insulator transition in a one dimensional device
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68344-0Energy gaps can be induced by spatial modulation of the electronic potential. title: Comprehensive benchmarking single and multi ancestry polygenic score methods with the PGS-hub platform
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 25 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68599-7Here the authors systematically benchmark 13 polygenic score (PGS) methods in UK Biobank European and African populations, revealing factors that affect prediction accuracy. They also introduce an automated platform for standardized and reproducible PGS computation.

title: Interaction and functional specialization across a distributed neural circuit for flexible task control in macaques
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65766-0Neural mechanism underlying behavioural flexibility is not fully understood. Here authors study decision-making of macaques in a reversal task. They identify two complementary cognitive processes. Distinct neural patterns link these processes to the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex, thalamus, and hippocampus.

title: Bernoulli’s principle-mediated Cl<sub>2</sub> electrosynthesis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66643-6The method for separating Cl2 based on the Bernoulli principle enables efficient electrochemical chlorine evolution under universal pH conditions in a three-phase system. This enables assembly of a membrane-free system that can resist the influence of pH changes in the electrolyte.

title: Entanglement-inspired frequency-agile rangefinding
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68589-9Quantum range finding struggles in bright background and at long distance. Here, the authors demonstrate a quantum-inspired, energy-time correlated classical rangefinder. It preserves quantum noise suppression, works at low power, and enables robust daylight remote ranging in real-world environments

title: Recreating viable YYh genotype uncovers the role of CpYYL underlying YY lethality in papaya
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68627-6Papaya is a trioecious species with XX females, XY males, and XYh hermaphrodites, and the combination of Y and Yh chromosomes is lethal. Here, the authors identify the degeneration of the YY lethality gene on the Y chromosome as the causal balancing lethal factor that reenforces dioecy and stabilizes balanced sex ratios.

title: BiG-SCAPE 2.0 and BiG-SLiCE 2.0: scalable, accurate and interactive sequence clustering of metabolic gene clusters
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68733-5BiG-SCAPE and BiG-SLiCE are computational tools that enable exploring the diversity of metabolic gene clusters across microbial genomes. Here, the authors present major updates to these tools, providing essential infrastructure for studying the diversity of microbial metabolism.

title: iDesignGPT enhances conceptual design via large language model agentic workflows
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68672-1Conceptual engineering design is challenged by its inherent complexity, dynamics, and creativity demands. Here, the authors integrate large language models with established design methodologies in a multiagent framework for early-stage conceptual design.

title: Molecular recognition of thyroglobulin by sortilin
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68658-zSortilin mediates thyroglobulin endocytosis within the thyroid. Using structural biology, the authors reveal that sortilin acts as structural sensor of monomeric thyroglobulin, independently of its iodination and hormone content, via binding of a flexible C-terminal peptide.

title: Residence time of Hunga stratospheric water vapour perturbation quantified at 9 years
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03216-5Stratospheric water vapour injected by the 2022 Hunga eruption has now entered a steady decay phase and is expected to return to its pre-eruption range around 2030. This estimate combines satellite observations with a global transport model.

title: Toward a sustainable megalopolis by reconciling power system decarbonization and urban health resilience
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03198-4Decarbonization of the power system is crucial for meeting climate goals, but it may unintentionally increase heat-related mortality in large urban areas such as Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao, according to an analysis that uses climate, weather, and health data and a statistical approach

title: High-resolution geomechanical modeling reveals accelerating infrastructure risks from permafrost degradation in Northern Alaska
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03240-5Accelerating ground settlement and reduced bearing capacity poses a critical threat to essential infrastructure due to permafrost degradation in Northern Alaska, according to integrated physics-constrained geotechnical model and process-based ground thermal modeling system.

title: Permafrost and wildfire carbon emissions indicate need for additional action to keep Paris Agreement temperature goals within reach
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03189-5Including permafrost and wildfire carbon emissions reduces the remaining allowable carbon budget for keeping the global average temperature increase below 1.5 degrees by 25%, according to Earth system model simulations.

title: Earlier spring onset and autumn warming increase the discrepancy between leaf coloration and photosynthetic cessation
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 24 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03239-yLeaf coloration is found later than photosynthetic cessation in autumn across northern ecosystems, and the discrepancy grows from 2001 to 2021, which is primarily due to earlier starts of growing seasons and autumn warming, as revealed by remote sensing and climate data

title: Global water security is threatened by rising inequality
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01909-8Projections using a machine-learning model, trained on historical socioeconomic and water-resources data, reveal the impact of inequality on water security and predict that, by 2100, 63% of the global population could face severe water scarcity. Pathways of societal development driven by technological efficiency could result in even greater inequality and water insecurity.

title: Atomically tweaking spin-crossover cooperativity to augment molecular memory density
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68796-4Spin-crossover complexes are promising candidates for molecular bits owing to their magnetic bistability but engineering high-density bits is challenging due to cooperative switching dynamics. Here the authors modulate the cooperative dynamics of surface-confined spin-crossover complex chains.

title: Meta-amplified dark-field interferometric scattering microscopy
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68697-6We introduce meta-amplified dark-field interferometric scattering microscopy, which uses a plasmonic metasurface to enhance sensitivity and contrast by converting nanoparticle-induced phase perturbations into strong far-field scattering signals.

title: Earthquakes act as a capacitor for terrestrial organic carbon
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68341-3Using the 2008 Wenchuan Earthquake, the authors show that earthquake-triggered landslides increased mountain carbon storage by ~10% from 2008 to 2020, as vegetation recovery and sediment burial retained carbon, revealing earthquakes and landslides function as long-term carbon capacitors.

title: Polar discontinuities, emergent conductivity, and critical twist-angle-dependent behaviour at wafer-bonded ferroelectric interfaces
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68553-7Wafer bonding has allowed the synthesis of twisted interfaces which support polar discontinuities in ferroelectric lithium niobate. Two-dimensional sheet conductivity arises but is suppressed when twist angles lead to interfacial lattice aperiodicity.

title: Homotypic membrane-powered electrochemical microfluidic analysis of extracellular vesicles for precise cancer diagnosis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68770-0The cancer cell membrane replicates the characteristic molecular profile of its parental cells. Here, authors construct a homotypic membrane-powered biomimetic interface for subtype-specific analysis of breast cancer extracellular vesicles.

title: Climate policy portfolios that accelerate emission reductions
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68577-zClimate policy portfolios reduce emissions but not fast enough for Paris Agreement goals. This study analyses 43 countries (2000–2022) and finds that specialised instruments, long-term targets, and dedicated governmental bodies are linked to faster emission cuts.

title: Imaging flow cytometry for palaeoclimate reconstruction
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43017-026-00760-8Edward Forman explains how imaging flow cytometry can quickly count particulates in samples from natural climate archives, such as sediment cores, to reconstruct past environmental conditions.

title: Rainfall amplified sea-level control on silicate weathering in the Indo-Pacific Convergence Zone during Quaternary glacials
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03219-2During glacial periods, silicate weathering fluxes in the Indo-Pacific Convergence Zone were 33% higher compared to interglacial periods, with rainfalls amplifying it to 54–130%, according to numerical simulation of silicate chemical weathering.

title: Maize cultivation and forest collapse over five centuries in southern China
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03224-5Introduction of maize cultivation, rapid population growth, and extensive deforestation triggered a persistent shift toward open landscapes after the 18th century, as revealed by a multi-proxy reconstruction of five centuries of land use and vegetation change in the karst landscapes of Southwest China.

title: Rethinking and comprehensive planning of the floating city concept

title: Positive glacial regulatory processes promote sustainability of Asian glacier water resources

title: Harnessing Van Hove singularities for terahertz photoresponse via Fermi surface reconstruction in kagome lattices
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66749-xThis study demonstrates a low-energy photon device based on the kagome metal RbV₃Sb₅. It demonstrates that Fermi surface reconstruction, driven by a phase transition, leads to the emergence of van Hove singularities near the Fermi level.

title: Atypical pericapillary Ly6G⁺Nur77⁺ macrophages initiate type-2 immune responses to allergens in the mouse lung
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68652-5The cellular mechanisms to initiate allergic responses involve various immune cells in the lungs. Here the authors identify a Ly6G+Nur77+ macrophage population involved in initiation of HDM-driven Th2 responses that detect Derp1 allergen through PAR2 and modulate migration of conventional DC to draining lymph nodes via cysteinyl leukotriene production.

title: Harnessing P<sup>V</sup>-oxirene for the modular synthesis of α-Oxy carbonyls
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68671-2α-Oxy carbonyl compounds represent versatile building blocks and modifiers for functional molecules, but the synthetic challenges have limited their exploration in chemical biology and drug discovery. Here, the authors report a Cu-catalyzed, three-component modular strategy for the efficient construction of diverse α-oxy carbonyl compounds, which proceeds via a P(V)-oxirene intermediate.

title: Assimilative causal inference
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68568-0The authors develop a framework that uses data assimilation to trace causes backwards from observed effects, even with partial observations. This assimilative causal inference enables online detection of instantaneous causal relationships and reveals how causal influence propagates temporally.

title: Camouflaged nanorobots target and regulate macrophage subcellular organelle crosstalk patterns to promote neural regeneration
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68636-5Macrophages play an important role in repair and regeneration of damaged nerves in spinal cord injury (SCI). Here, Guo et al. investigate effects of endoplasmic reticulum-mitochondria crosstalk on macrophage phenotype and develop a targeted nanorobot inhibiting the Ero1α/MAMs/mtCa²⁺ axis, promoting M2 polarization and neural repair as a therapeutic strategy to treat SCI.

title: No evidence of immediate or persistent analgesic effect from a single dose of psilocybin in three mouse models of pain
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68763-zPsilocybin may help treat chronic pain, possibly due to direct analgesic effects. Here, authors tested psilocybin on acute and chronic pain in three mouse models of pain and found minimal effects on sensory, affective, or functional pain measures.

title: Phosphorothioate DNA modification by BREX type 4 systems in the human gut microbiome
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68412-5Here, the authors combine bioinformatic, mass spectrometric, and sequencing-based mapping tools to identify previously undescribed phosphorothioate epigenetic systems widespread in the human gut microbiome.

title: Evaluating single-cell ATAC-seq atlasing technologies using sequence-to-function modeling
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68742-4Generating high-quality training data for machine learning is costly. Here, authors include sequence-to-function modeling in benchmarking of custom and commercial droplet-based scATAC platforms, and release a new Drosophila embryo atlas along with a new mouse cortex atlas, assessed for model interpretability.

title: Changes in terrestrial weathering following glacial retreat reveal processes altering North Atlantic neodymium isotopes
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03220-9Variations in shield-derived sediment influx and weathering extent affect the Nd isotopic composition of North Atlantic seawater and seafloor sediments, according to Nd isotopic data from southwest Greenland.

title: Anthropogenic emissions of volatile Cd detected in western tropical North Atlantic surface seawater
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03211-wAnthropogenic Cd contributes at least 19%, and possibly more than 45%, of the dissolved Cd in surface water of the western tropical Atlantic Ocean, according to a box model based on measured seawater profiles of Cd concentrations and isotopic compositions.

title: Green mining policies reduce carbon emissions in Chinese coal production bases
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03223-6Green mining policies cut coal production emissions by 43.6 million tons annually across China’s coal bases, as shown by interrupted time series analysis linking policy intensity to emission trends from 2004–2021.

title: Short-term Antarctic ice-sheet dynamics during the late Oligocene
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03217-4The Antarctic ice sheet during the late Oligocene (26.2–25.2 million years ago) was highly dynamic, alternating between near-modern size during glacial periods and smaller volumes during interglacials, driven by orbitally-paced climate variations, according to a high-resolution multi-proxy record.

title: A mantle source formed after the lunar magma ocean crystallisation for the 3000 Ma-old lunar basalts
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03002-9Measurements of lead isotopes from 3 billion year old low-titanium lunar basalts reveal a unique enriched mantle source, distinct from KREEP, which likely formed after the crystallisation of the lunar magma ocean via deep crust-breaking impacts

title: Continental river runoff enhances atmospheric aerosol formation over the Arctic Ocean
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02986-8Riverine dissolved organic matter input and subsequent new particle formation is a major source of Arctic aerosol which has been largely overlooked, according to analysis of atmospheric particle number size distributions from Tiksi, Russia.

title: Ship fuel sulfur content regulations may exacerbate mass coral bleaching events on the Great Barrier Reef
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03088-1Reduced sulfate aerosols due to ship fuel regulation may increase shortwave radiation on the Great Barrier Reef, exacerbating the impact of marine heatwaves on coral bleaching, according to model analysis of ship emission impacts on aerosols, clouds and solar radiation.

summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10013-1An extreme barocaloric effect in NH4SCN aqueous solutions is enabled by pressure-induced dissolution and precipitation, but without using a separate heat-transfer liquid.

title: Temporal tissue dynamics from a spatial snapshot
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09876-1One-shot tissue dynamics reconstruction can infer changes in tissue composition over time, from single-time-point spatial proteomics of human cancers.

title: Symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09883-2The symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism are reviewed, and compared with traditional ferromagnetism and Néel antiferromagnetism, and magnetic phases with symmetry-protected compensated non-collinear spin orders.

title: Pyramidal neurons proportionately alter cortical interneuron subtypes
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09996-8Pyramidal neuron-driven mechanisms actively promote the survival and terminal differentiation of their associated interneuron subtypes.

title: Rock art from at least 67,800 years ago in Sulawesi
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09968-yA hand stencil painted on a cave wall on a small island off the coast of Sulawesi more than 67,800 years ago suggests a very early occupation of Wallacea.

title: Core–envelope miscibility in sub-Neptunes and super-Earths
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09970-4First-principles molecular dynamics driven by density functional theory is used to show that silicate and hydrogen are completely miscible over a wide range of plausible core–envelope pressure–temperature conditions.

title: Four camera-type eyes in the earliest vertebrates from the Cambrian Period
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09966-0Early vertebrates, particularly myllokunmingids, possessed four camera-type eyes (a pair of lateral eyes and pineal and parapineal organs), which indicates that these structures functioned in image formation, in support of the hypothesis that the four camera-type eyes represent an ancestral vertebrate trait.

title: Identification of an allosteric site on the E3 ligase adapter cereblon
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09994-wAn allosteric site on the E3 ligase adapter cereblon can be targeted to modulate the efficacy of cereblon in targeted protein degradation applications.

title: Predatory aggression evolved through adaptations to noradrenergic circuits
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10009-xNoradrenergic circuits support and balance aggressive behavioural states in predatory nematodes, distinguish predatory from non-predatory nematode species and are associated with the evolution of complex behavioural traits.

title: The potential for bridgmanite megacrysts to drive magma ocean segregation
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10063-5Large-scale molecular dynamics simulations show that the crystal–melt interfacial energies of MgSiO3 bridgmanite increase substantially with pressure, potentially forming unusually large bridgmanite crystals and suggesting a new physical mechanism driving magma ocean segregation.

title: Ageing promotes microglial accumulation of slow-degrading synaptic proteins
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09987-9Newly developed mouse models that enable cell-specific analyses of proteostasis dynamics across the lifespan of the mice reveal key aspects of neuronal proteostasis with ageing.

title: Oxygen-free metabolism in the bird inner retina supported by the pecten
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09978-wWhile the photoreceptor outer segments in the bird outer retina have access to oxygen, the inner retina operates under chronic anoxia, supported by anaerobic glycolysis in the retinal neurons.

title: Critical role for a high-plasticity cell state in lung cancer
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09985-xThe high-plasticity cell state (HPCS) is a critical hub that enables reciprocal transitions between cancer cell states, and targeting the HPCS may suppress cancer progression and eradicate treatment resistance.

title: Large-scale dynamos driven by shear-flow-induced jets
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09912-0Aadvanced computer simulations of three-dimensional turbulence reveal that the ab initio generation of large-scale magnetic fields is driven by shear-flow-induced jets; an analytical model is derived which reproduces the essential features of the flow- and field-generation mechanisms.

title: Common variation in meiosis genes shapes human recombination and aneuploidy
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09964-2Analysis of data from pre-implantation genetic testing sheds light on the genetic basis of meiotic-origin aneuploidy, the leading cause of human pregnancy loss, identifying common genetic variants associated with maternal meiotic errors.

title: Dissecting gene regulatory networks governing human cortical cell fate
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09997-7Systematic screening of transcription factors reveals conserved mechanisms governing cortical radial glia lineage progression across primates and provides a framework for functional dissection of gene regulatory networks in human cortical neurogenesis.

title: Quantum spin resonance in engineered proteins for multimodal sensing
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09971-3A recently developed class of magneto-sensitive fluorescent proteins are engineered to alter the properties of their response to magnetic fields and radio frequencies, enabling multimodal sensing of biological systems.

title: LetA defines a structurally distinct transporter family
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09990-0The distinct architecture of the Escherichia coli membrane transporter LetA mediates lipid trafficking across the bacterial envelope in partnership with the tunnel-like complex LetB.

title: Probing quantum mechanics with nanoparticle matter-wave interferometry
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09917-9Quantum interference of sodium nanoparticles, which can each contain more than 7,000 atoms at masses greater than 170,000 Da, is demonstrated.

title: Relatively warm deep-water formation persisted in the Last Glacial Maximum
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10012-2During the Last Glacial Maximum, the deep Northwest Atlantic was only about 2 °C colder than today, suggesting sustained production of relatively warm North Atlantic Deep Water during the Last Glacial Maximum.

title: Baby-to-baby strain transmission shapes the developing gut microbiome
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09983-zA metagenomic survey of babies attending the first year of nursery detected extensive baby-to-baby microbial strain transmission, pointing to social interactions in infancy as crucial drivers of infant microbiome development.

title: Fibre integrated circuits by a multilayered spiral architecture
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09974-0Fibre integrated circuits created by first preparing circuitry on extremely thin and flexible substrates and then mechanically rolling them up demonstrate microdevice density reaching 100,000 transistors per centimetre and excellent stability under harsh service conditions.

title: Fibroblastic reticular cells direct the initiation of T cell responses via CD44
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09988-8CD44 expressed by fibroblastic reticular cells in secondary lymphoid organs regulates trafficking of dendritic cells, and thus has an essential role in the priming of T cells and the adaptive immune response.

title: Biological insights into schizophrenia from ancestrally diverse populations
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10000-6Genome-wide association studies incorporating data for populations of African ancestry provide an expanded view of the genetic basis of schizophrenia, which has previously been studied mainly in European and East Asian cohorts.

title: Accretion bursts crystallize silicates in a planet-forming disk
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09939-3The detection of forsterite and enstatite emissions in EC 53 during accretion bursts marks one of the first pieces of direct evidence of in situ silicate crystallization in young stars.

title: Convergent evolution of scavenger cell development at brain borders
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10003-3Transcription factor osr2 is identified as a specific marker and regulator of mural lymphatic endothelial cell (muLEC) differentiation and maintenance, and muLECs and border-associated macrophages share functional analogies but are not homologous, providing an example of convergent evolution.

title: Atmospheric microplastic emissions from land and ocean
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09998-6A global atmospheric microplastics dataset is compiled, and comparison with size-aligned microplastic models in the literature indicate that fewer microplastic particles are emitted into the atmosphere than previously thought.

title: The transition from monocyte to tissue-resident macrophage requires DHPS
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09972-2In mice, DHPS supports the maturation, maintenance and function of tissue-resident macrophages via the polyamine–hypusine axis, with implications for macrophage-targeting therapies.

title: Untangling the connection between dopamine and ADHD
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00094-xDopamine signals have long been a target for ADHD treatments. Now, researchers are learning how the neurotransmitter influences the condition.

title: Quantum effect observed for biggest objects yet
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04097-yAn experiment has broken the size record for an object exhibiting matter-wave interference — fuelling the debate about possible size constraints.

title: Six highlights from ADHD research
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00099-6Key studies and trials examine genetic mutations, the impact on life expectancy, cognitive impairments and other aspects of this condition.

title: More than half of authors of leading research say funding is declining
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00054-5Nature Index ‘Research Leaders’ survey also finds that scientists in North America and Europe are much more likely to say they intend to leave research.

title: Illuminating how the bird inner retina works without oxygen solves a 350-year-old structural mystery
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04095-0Neurons in the bird eye’s inner retina lack a blood supply. Finding how these neurons function without oxygen reveals a role for an enigmatic eye structure.

title: Schrödinger’s cat just got bigger: quantum physicists create largest ever ‘superposition’
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00177-9Record-breaking experiment shows that a cluster of thousands of atoms can act like a wave as well as a particle.

title: Is paracetamol in pregnancy a risk factor for ADHD?
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00097-8A common pain reliever taken in pregnancy might raise the risk of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, according to research in the past decade. But proof of cause and effect remains elusive.

title: A variety of early hominin species shared the Afar region of Ethiopia
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03727-9Fossils reveal that at least four types of hominin, including Paranthropus, were present in northern Ethiopia between 3 million and 2.4 million years ago.

title: ADHD treatments move beyond stimulants
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00095-wResearchers are developing drugs to broaden the options on available therapies.

title: The rich stopped buying yachts the year time went on sale
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03605-4Second thoughts.

title: Sending babies to nursery completely reshapes their microbiomes
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00178-8Socializing at a young age helps to develop greater diversity in their microbiota, according to an analysis of baby-to-baby transmission of gut bacteria.

title: An eye-popping discovery: early vertebrates had four eyes rather than two
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04096-zEyes on a face’s front or side enable a brain to perceive images. Fossil evidence suggests that two light-sensitive organs on top of ancient vertebrate heads generated images, too.

title: Why ADHD goes undiagnosed in girls
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00098-7Differences in how the condition presents in girls, and co-occurring psychiatric conditions, make detection more difficult.

title: AI and nuclear energy feature strongly in agenda-setting technologies for 2026
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00185-9Nature’s annual list of technologies to watch is a chance to celebrate progress and stimulate research into both opportunities and risks.

title: Hand stencils in Indonesian cave are world’s oldest known artworks
summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00018-9Rock art found in Indonesia dates to at least 67,800 years ago, representing the earliest known cave art made by humans. These findings provide insights into the movement and cultural lives of populations that contributed to the ancestry of Indigenous Australian and Papuan people.

summary: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00204-9The discovery that some fluorescent proteins are sensitive to magnets could lead to the development of switchable drugs and biosensors.

title: Evolution of the tuberculin skin test reveals generalisable Mtb-reactive T cell metaclones
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68678-9T cells contribute to protection and pathogenesis in tuberculosis. Here the authors sequence T cell receptor repertoires in human skin biopsies from the site of the tuberculin skin test and show enrichment of clonotypes reactive to Mycobacterium tuberculosis using a computational pipeline metaclonotypist to identify distinct TCRs predicted to share peptide-MHC reactivity across participants, as an approach to explore T cell correlates of tuberculosis disease-risk stratification and vaccine efficacy.

title: An ultra-long-acting dimeric bictegravir prodrug defined by a short pharmacokinetic tail
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68501-5Current long acting HIV therapies face challenges like prolonged pharmacokinetic tails, which increase resistance risk. The authors develop dimeric bictegravir prodrug nanosuspensions that sustain therapeutic levels for six months with a short PK tail, supporting safer ultra-long-acting HIV treatment.

title: Sugar rationing during the first 1000 days of life and lifelong risk of heart failure
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68713-9High sugar intake is a potential risk factor for heart failure, but there is insufficient evidence for the benefit of restricting sugar intake during pregnancy or early life. Using the end of UK sugar rationing as a natural experiment, this study shows that lower sugar intake early in life is linked to lower risk of heart failure and later disease onset.

title: Serine inhibits granulosa cell ferroptosis to maintain ovarian function
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68440-1This study demonstrates that the reduced serum serine in patients with chemotherapy or women with poor sleep, is linked to the decline of ovarian function. Serine supplementation prevented ovarian damage in mice by inhibiting ferroptosis in ovarian granulosa cells, without affecting chemotherapy efficacy.

title: Observation of strong spin-orbit couplings in plasmonic spin-twistronics topological lattices
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68629-4Twistronics is commonly applied to a twisted bilayer of two-dimensional materials. Here, authors introduce the concepts of twistronics to the superposition of two spin lattices generated from surface plasmon polaritons on a single surface. The system is periodically modulated by its total angular momentum.

title: From TDP-43/RNA complex formation to disease-linked TDP-43 aggregation through a structural and cellular approach
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68346-yFeng et al. unravel the structural basis of TDP-43 higher-order assemblies with mRNA and the structural changes leading to TDP-43 aggregation, which are associated with neurodegenerative diseases such as Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

title: ZNF683<sup>+</sup> NK cells govern chemotherapy sensitivity in advanced HPSCC via reshaping immune microenvironment
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68676-xIn patients with hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (HPSCC), resistance to the standard-of-care induction chemotherapy often occurs. Here, using longitudinal single-cell transcriptomic profiling of HPSCC samples from patients receiving induction chemotherapy, the authors identify a ZNF683-high natural killer (NK) cell population as a predictor of chemotherapy response.

title: Using litterfall nets to study enhanced rock weathering
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43017-026-00763-5Isabella Steeley explains how litterfall nets are used in the monitoring of nutrient cycling in forest environments where enhanced rock weathering has been applied.

title: Silicic magma reservoir anisotropy persists through protracted crystallization and low strain rates
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03214-7A partially molten sill-complex structure is found within the slowly crystallizing and tectonically quiet magma reservoir beneath Valles Caldera using anisotropic Rayleigh and Love wave tomography.

title: Zinc isotopes record lunar magmatic outgassing and surface processes in different Chang’e-5 samples
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03215-6Zinc isotope data from Chang’e-5 lunar basalt samples records early impact driven volatile depletion, whereas soil samples primarily record late-stage volcanic degassing, with only limited space-weathering modification.

title: Self-organization of mid-ocean ridge segments during oblique oceanisation
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03201-yOblique spreading at slow to ultraslow rates fosters asymmetric growth of the ocean floor and leads to spontaneous formation of orthogonal ridge segments and new transform faults, according to thermomechanical simulations.

title: Detrital zircon–apatite fingerprinting challenges glacial transport of Stonehenge’s megaliths
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03105-3Salisbury Plain detrital zircon ages align with southern British rocks from the London Basin, indicating local sedimentary recycling without glaciogenic evidence, negating glacial transport of the Stonehenge blocks, according to detrital zircon and apatite U-Pb isotopic fingerprinting of stream sediments across the Salisbury Plain.
