title: Sedimentary conditions drive modern pyrite burial flux to exceed oxidation
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01855-5Modern pyrite burial in seafloor sediments exceeds pyrite oxidation on land, indicating that the sulfur cycle is out of balance, and acts to increase atmospheric oxygen levels, according to a diagenetic model validated by sediment cores.

title: Infant gut anellovirus composition associates with early life factors and childhood atopic disease
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66732-6Here, the authors characterize the gut virome of 647 one-year-old children in the COPSAC2010 cohort, finding that anelloviruses are highly prevalent and associated with daycare attendance, gestational age, and FUT2 secretor status.

title: Redox-Improved Self-Assembled Monolayers for Inverted Perovskite Solar Cells
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66421-4Variations in the valence states of nickel oxide hinder the growth of a uniform self-assembled monolayer (SAM). Here, authors develop a SAM with the oxidized product forming S−O−Ni bond at Ni3+-rich regions, achieving maximum device efficiency of 26.5% in operationally stable perovskite solar cells.

title: Isofrequency spin-wave imaging using color center magnetometry for magnon spintronics
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67056-1Color center magnetometry enables spin-wave imaging in complex magnetic textures. This work overcomes key limitations of current approaches by decoupling sensor spins from control fields and using diamond and hBN color centers for complementary frequency operation, achieving isofrequency imaging of field-controlled spin waves.

title: Supersolidophobic Pt catalyst for long-term natural seawater electrolysis with hydrogen production and magnesium extraction
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66473-6Electrochemical synthesis of solid compounds is an emerging frontier in electrocatalysis. Here, the authors report a Pt catalyst whose surface-coordinated halogens alleviate the scaling effect by regulating the local environment and enable simultaneous Mg(OH)₂ and H₂ production from natural seawater.

title: Concurrent TB and HIV therapies control TB reactivation during co-infection but not chronic immune activation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67188-4The basis for inefficient Mtb control in PLWH despite treatment is unclear. Here, the authors show that combined TB/HIV therapy in Mtb/SIV co-infected macaques reduces bacterial and viral burden and improved lung pathology, but failed to fully restore immune balance, revealing persistent inflammation.

title: The long non-coding RNA UGDH-AS1 encodes an NK-cell-inhibiting micropeptide in triple-negative breast cancers
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66266-xDysfunctional NK cells contribute to the immune-hostile tumour microenvironment of triple-negative breast cancers (TNBC). Here authors show that NKSM, a micropeptide encoded by the long non-coding RNA UGDH-AS1, is specifically expressed in the intra-tumoral NK cells in TNBC and interferes with their anti-tumour activity.

title: Hyperglycemia exacerbates osteoarthritis by impairing macrophage efferocytosis through modulation of CD11b lactylation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67473-2Diabetes, a frequent co-morbidity to osteoarthritis, accelerates progression of joint inflammation. Here author show that hyperglycaemia enhances glycolysis in synovial macrophages, leading to increased lactylation of CD11b, which impairs the capacity of macrophages to phagocytose apoptotic cells, which eventually aggravates inflammation.

title: Mediators of the association between psychological distress and mortality in people diagnosed with cancer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66059-2Psychological distress is associated with a range of adverse outcomes in people living with and beyond cancer (LWBC). In here, the authors find that psychological distress is associated with an increased risk of all-cause and cancer mortality in people with LWBC, partly due to high systemic inflammation. However, evidence for mediation by health behaviours is found to be inconsistent.

title: Super-resolution wind mapping with deep learning for scalable renewable energy planning
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03072-9Super-resolution wind mapping is possible through combined frequency-based filtering and generative adversarial architecture, suggests a deep learning-based framework validated with a point-to-grid Monte Carlo evaluation scheme

title: Modelling of earthquake swarms suggests magmatic fluids in the upper crust beneath the Eger Rift
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03019-0A seismic swarm on the Czech/German border in 2024 began with an initial phase of hydro-fracturing followed by a higher magnitude phase of fault slip and hydro-shearing, resolved from a high-resolution seismic catalogue and fluid intrusion models.

title: Terrestrial atmospheric ion implantation occurred in the nearside lunar regolith during the history of Earth’s dynamo
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02960-4Numerical simulations reveal that the transfer of ions from Earth’s atmosphere to the Moon is efficient only in the sustained presence of a geomagnetic field, suggesting that lunar soils may record the histories of the atmosphere, solar wind, and geodynamo.

title: Structures of human glucose-6-phosphate transporter reveal reciprocal antiport mechanism driving glucose-6-phosphate and inorganic phosphate exchange
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66386-4Human Glucose-6- phosphate Transporter (G6PT1) is critical for systemic glucose homeostasis. By integrating multiple cryo-EM structures with functional validation, the study elucidates the molecular mechanism of G6PT1 and its dysregulation in glycogen storage disease.

title: BPTF regulates androgen receptor activity by enhancing chromatin accessibility and stabilizing the AR-FOXA1 interaction
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67329-9BPTF is a scaffolding subunit of the nucleosome remodeling factor (NURF) complex. Here the authors show that BPTF is upregulated in prostate cancer cells, increases chromatin accessibility at Androgen Receptor (AR)-binding sites, and stabilizes the AR-FOXA1 complex.

title: High single-pass conversion of nitrous oxide to dinitrogen in gas-diffusion-electrolyzer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67244-zEfficient single-pass conversion poses a challenge in N2O electroreduction. Here, the authors report a gas-diffusion-electrolyzer system using a CuAg catalyst that achieves 79.4% single-pass N2O conversion, offering a cost-effective pathway for greenhouse gas mitigation.

title: Curvature-engineered interfacial hydrogen-bond networks driving proton-coupled electron transfer boosts hydrogen oxidation in alkaline fuel cells
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66360-0The sluggish hydrogen oxidation reaction hinders the development of anion exchange membrane fuel cells. Here, the authors develop high-curvature RuIr CNCs that induce an O-down water orientation, thereby strengthening hydrogen-bond networks and reducing proton transfer barriers.

title: Mechanistic insights into single-stranded DNA degradation by lysosomal exonucleases PLD3 and PLD4 from structural snapshots
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66261-2PLD3 and PLD4 are endolysosomal exonucleases that modulate TLR7 and TLR9 responses. The authors report cryoEM structures capturing distinct catalytic states, providing mechanistic insights into single-stranded DNA degradation by PLD3 and PLD4.

title: Enhanced tunable X-rays from bulk crystals driven by table-top free electron energies
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66063-6The authors demonstrate tunable x-ray generation from free-electron-driven van der Waals bulk crystals. This overturns the notion that parametric x-rays are only possible with very thin films or highly relativistic electrons and show record enhancement of the x-ray output.

title: Topological quantum cascade laser with Dirac-scaled valley edge modes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66525-xTopological lasers offer robust performance but often at the cost of a large non-lasing bulk. Here, the authors propose a Dirac-scaled quantum cascade laser that expands the lasing mode volume while maintaining robustness against structural defects.

title: Co-condensation between transcription factor and cBAF selectively modulates chromatin remodeling and gene expression
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67322-2Activation of genes depends on transcription factors and chromatin remodelers. Here, the authors show ARID1A organizes these components through phase separation, co-condensing with specific transcription factors to maintain chromatin accessibility and drive gene expression.

title: Glacier biogeochemical cycling and downstream impacts
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00751-1Far from frozen and sterile environments, glaciers are biogeochemical reactors and regulators. This Review outlines key biogeochemical and associated physical processes occurring in glacierized environments and the known impacts of glaciers on elemental cycling and the Earth system.

title: Ecological levers for microbially driven water treatment enhance pollutant removal prediction
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02996-6Microbial ecological indicators significantly enhance pollutant removal prediction by 37% compared to models based only on process parameters, according to a machine-learned framework developed with performance data across 648 globally distributed biofilters.

title: Cross-continental soil prokaryotic traits driven by precipitation regime and land cover
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03028-zSmall genomes and high maximal growth of soil prokaryotes occurred in barren soils and soils with high precipitation seasonality, while large genomes and low growth appeared in moist, resource-rich forests, based on marker gene-based trait analysis of samples from Greenland, Europe, and South Africa.

title: Strong impact of tropical cyclones on the genesis of subsurface marine heatwaves
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02992-wTropical cyclones trigger up to 40% of subsurface marine heatwaves in cyclone-active regions, according to in situ observations and ocean reanalysis, which also suggests their area and intensity have increased over the past two decades due to long-term ocean warming.

title: Characterizing the vertical structure of forests in the Brazilian Amazon
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02976-wVertical structure of forests in the Brazilian Amazon varies with secondary forest age and is affected by multiple disturbances, and forests in the region can be classified into 5 types, according to an airborne LiDAR dataset covering over 188,000 hectares.

title: Interaction of multiple triggering mechanisms during the 2023 Jishishan earthquake sequence
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02985-9Finite source modelling using geodetic and teleseismic data suggest that aftershocks on the main fault were triggered primarily by static stress changes, whereas those along the conjugate fault network were driven by volumetric strain and fluid injection

title: Glimmers of hope for a deadly disease
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03941-5New models, efforts for early detection and better therapies may help change pancreatic cancer’s aggressive course.

title: Will young universities set the pace in the age of AI?
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03949-xWhy some institutions are betting on technology to stay relevant.

title: Exposing a silent cancer
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03942-4Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest malignancies, and it is increasingly occurring in young people — especially women. An uptick in research funding is a welcome development in the push to transform treatment.

title: Neanderthals mastered fire — 400,000 years ago
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04059-4Archaeological evidence makes a compelling case for Neanderthal-created fires 400,000 years ago in Suffolk, UK — plus, how chatbots can sway the opinions of voters.

title: Fasting boosts breast cancer therapy efficacy via glucocorticoid activation
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09869-0Beneficial effects of fasting combined with endocrine therapy for oestrogen receptor-α-expressing breast cancers can be recapitulated using exogenous glucocorticoid receptor ligands instead of fasting to reduce harmful effects.

title: The influence of short-lived halogens on atmospheric chemistry and climate
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09753-xA Review of the impacts of short-lived halogens on air quality and climate identifies gaps in our knowledge of short-lived halogen emissions, chemistry, and the environmental and climate impacts.

title: Quantifying grain boundary deformation mechanisms in small-grained metals
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09800-7Experimental observations in small-grained polycrystals suggest a new concept of considering metallic grain boundaries not as defects but as separate defect-containing lattices, providing a potential explanation for the deformation behaviour of nanocrystalline metals.

title: Gene-drive-capable mosquitoes suppress patient-derived malaria in Tanzania
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09685-6Engineering of local Anopheles gambiae under containment enables the generation of a transgenic strain equipped with non-autonomous gene drive capabilities that robustly inhibits genetically diverse Plasmodium falciparum isolates obtained from naturally infected children.

title: Erythropoietin receptor on cDC1s dictates immune tolerance
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09824-zThe tolerogenic activity of type 1 conventional dendritic cells (cDC1s) is determined by EPOR, which is preferentially expressed in cDC1s and induces antigen-specific FOXP3-expressing regulatory T cells.

title: Human gut M cells resemble dendritic cells and present gluten antigen
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09829-8An intestinal organoid model recapitulates human microfold (M) cell function and transcriptomic profiling and biochemical assays demonstrate that M cells uptake and present antigens to the immune system via the class II major histocompatibility complex.

title: Cross-regulation of [2Fe–2S] cluster synthesis by ferredoxin-2 and frataxin
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09822-1A finely balanced ratio of ferredoxin-2 (FDX2) and frataxin (FXN) is essential for the synthesis of iron–sulfur clusters, and interventions targeting this ratio could provide a way to treat related diseases, such as Friedreich’s ataxia.

title: Sterilization and contraception increase lifespan across vertebrates
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09836-9Data collected from zoos and aquariums worldwide show that hormonal contraception or permanent surgical sterilization in mammals increase life expectancy, with different mechanisms in males and females.

title: Earliest evidence of making fire
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09855-6Baked sediment, heat-shattered artefacts and introduced pyrite in a 400,000-year-old Palaeolithic occupation site in Suffolk, UK provide evidence of intentional fire-making, marking a pivotal moment in human development.

title: Observation of deuteron and antideuteron formation from resonance-decay nucleons
authors: J. G. M. C. A. Arneiro
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09775-5The ALICE Collaboration provides details on the microscopic mechanism that ends up creating antideuteron in high-energy proton–proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider.

title: Hot droughts in the Amazon provide a window to a future hypertropical climate
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09728-yThirty years of forest demographic data, combined with recent ecophysiological measurements, reveal that intense Amazon droughts sharply increase tree mortality once soil moisture falls below a threshold, and that these hot droughts will become more frequent and intense as Earth warms towards hypertropical conditions.

title: A direct role for a mitochondrial targeting sequence in signalling stress
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09834-xCells can sense mitochondrial damage through signalling via an unimported mitochondrial targeting sequence.

title: Neutrophils preserve energy storage in sympathetically activated adipocytes
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09839-6Neutrophil-derived IL-1β has a role in preserving lipid stores during metabolic stress.

title: Mapping the genetic landscape across 14 psychiatric disorders
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09820-3Genomic analyses applied to 14 childhood- and adult-onset psychiatric disorders identifies five underlying genomic factors that explain the majority of the genetic variance of the individual disorders.

title: An RNA splicing system that excises DNA transposons from animal mRNAs
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09853-8A new type of mRNA splicing mechanism discovered in Caenorhabditis elegans that detects and removes inverted repeats also occurs in human cells, thereby providing another strategy to protect against the negative effects of transposable elements.

title: Uncovering the role of LINE-1 in the evolution of lung adenocarcinoma
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09825-yLung adenocarcinomas bearing the ID2 mutational signature display increased LINE-1 retrotransposon activity, which contributes to their fast evolutionary dynamics and aggressive phenotype.

title: Somatic evolution following cancer treatment in normal tissue
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09792-4High-depth sequencing of non-cancerous tissue from patients with metastatic cancer reveals single-base mutational signatures of alcohol, smoking and cancer treatments, and reveals how exogenous factors, including cancer therapies, affect somatic cell evolution.

title: Protected area management has significant spillover effects on vegetation
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09837-8Analysis of effect sizes of vegetation spillovers from protected areas in Australia shows that 71% of over 3,063 analysed protected areas had a positive spillover effect, and that these effects covary with protected area management type.

title: Laser-based conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy of <sup>229</sup>ThO<sub>2</sub>
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09776-4Laser-induced conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy, which detects electrons emitted by 229Th nuclei in a thin ThO2 sample excited by vacuum ultraviolet light, is demonstrated, opening the possibility of a conversion-electron-based nuclear clock.

title: Agonists for cytosolic bacterial receptor ALPK1 induce antitumour immunity
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09828-9The ALPK1 agonist UDSP-Hep stimulates tumour-cell antigen presentation, macrophage–DC cross-priming and differentiation of protective memory T cells.

title: Causal modelling of gene effects from regulators to programs to traits
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09866-3Approaches combining genetic association and Perturb-seq data that link genetic variants to functional programs to traits are described.

title: Mutations in mitochondrial ferredoxin FDX2 suppress frataxin deficiency
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09821-2A forward genetic screen in Caenorhabditis elegans reveals that decreased levels of the ferredoxin FDX2 suppress the loss of frataxin in worms and in mice by relief of FDX2 inhibition of frataxin-stimulated NFS1 activity.

title: Gut micro-organisms associated with health, nutrition and dietary interventions
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09854-7Comprehensive large-scale studies of multi-national populations identified microbiome species consistently associated with favourable and unfavourable health markers, informing future studies of the human gut microbiome and its association with diet and cardiometabolic conditions.

title: Pancreatic cancer is evasive. Is the nervous system the reason why?
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03943-3A growing body of research suggests tumours rely on proteins and genes that are unique to the nervous system to persist in the body.

title: Six highlights from pancreatic cancer research
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03948-yUnpacking risk factors, disease aggressiveness and other key work.

title: What would an AI university look like and how might it change education?
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03950-4From lectures by avatars to entire qualifications, higher education centred around AI is just around the corner.

title: A breathalyser-style test for detecting pancreatic cancer
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03946-0Surgeon George Hanna is developing a non-invasive test to catch one of the deadliest cancers before it’s too late.

title: Is your brain tired? Researchers are discovering the roots of mental fatigue
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03974-wBetter ways to measure cognitive exhaustion could point to treatments for long COVID and other debilitating disorders.

title: A giant catalogue of microscopic species across Denmark
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03819-6The Microflora Danica project has catalogued the microbial diversity of environmental habitats across Denmark and established an improved taxonomic reference database. As well as providing a special record of nitrogen-oxidizing microorganisms, the data set serves as a national baseline for tracking future microbial responses to factors such as land-use change and global warming.

title: SOS: RNA-processing mechanism rescues genes from invasive DNA
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03734-wTransposable elements can insert into genes, disrupting protein-coding potential. Researchers discover a mode of RNA processing, ‘SOS splicing’, that provides a quick fix.

title: But only just
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04022-3Making scents of things.

title: The pancreatic cancer models helping to drive innovation in the field
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03944-2Cellular, animal and computational models of the disease are providing fresh insights into biology and treatment.

title: China is leading the world on AI governance: other countries must engage
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03972-yThe nation’s regulators are attempting to match the rapid pace at which AI is evolving. That needs to become a global initiative.

title: Four young universities share their strategies for success
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03951-3Nimble, responsive and collaborative, these institutions stand out in the Nature Index.

title: A simple slipknot for precise force control
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03829-4The tension of conventional surgical sutures can affect wound healing and is dependent on the surgeon’s experience. Imaging and simulations reveal that slipknots can reproducibly store and release force, enabling precise and consistent surgical knotting without the need for electronic sensors or specialized equipment.

title: Nuclear clocks could use electrical signals to keep time
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03732-yThe emission of photons by excited nuclei has been explored for timekeeping and sensing, but nuclear processes that eject electrons offer practical advantages.

title: Huge genetic study reveals hidden links between psychiatric conditions
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04037-wAnalysis of more than 1 million people shows that mental-health disorders fall into five clusters, each of them linked to a specific set of genetic variants.

title: Genetically engineered mosquitoes block development of circulating malaria strains
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03577-5The genetic engineering of mosquitoes offers a potentially transformative, self-sustaining opportunity for malaria control and elimination in Africa. By rendering mosquitoes unable to transmit the malaria parasite, even when they bite humans, the technology provides a mosquito-based intervention to complement existing efforts.

title: Therapeutic vaccines can challenge pancreatic cancer before it takes hold
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03947-zSpecific protein targets and personalized vaccines have the potential to increase survival rates for the disease.

title: The brain’s speech centre responds to universal and specific features of language
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03827-6More than 7,000 languages are spoken around the world, but the human brain becomes highly specialized to process speech in an individual’s own language. Recordings from human brains reveal the shared and language-specific neural mechanisms that arise in the superior temporal gyrus to achieve this feat.

title: Shared genetic risk in psychiatric disorders
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03728-8Scientists have characterized the broad genetic patterns that are shared across 14 psychiatric disorders. Could it reframe how mental-health conditions are diagnosed?

title: Early detection could improve pancreatic cancer’s poor survival rates
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03945-1The disease is often caught too late to affect a person’s prognosis — scientists are looking to change that.

title: Oldest known evidence of the controlled ignition of fire
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03735-9A 400,000-year-old site excavated in England reveals signs of deliberate fires made using the mineral iron pyrite to produce sparks.

title: PTEN regulates vagal-insulin signaling to optimize autonomic output determining peripheral inflammatory and metabolic homeostasis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67192-8The vagus nerve is known to promote rest and digest, to counter physiologic stresses. Here, authors show that insulin signaling plays a critical role in optimizing autonomic function to maintain metabolic and inflammatory homeostasis.

title: Rising worldwide challenges to climate-induced extreme low-production events of photovoltaic and wind power
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67428-7This work shows that climate change is projected to unevenly intensify extreme low-production events in solar and wind power systems worldwide, highlighting the need for mitigation and adaptation to ensure future power reliability.

title: Structural insights into clonal restriction and diversity in T cell recognition of two immunodominant SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid epitopes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66322-6Previous structural studies of T cell recognition of SARS-CoV-2 have been confined to spike epitopes. Here the authors assess T cell recognition of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid epitopes, which are more conserved than spike epitopes, providing structural insights into recognition of two epitopes.

title: All-metallic magnetic Purcell enhancement in a thermally stable room-temperature maser
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66016-zDielectric structures that enhance magnetic emission are key for quantum devices but often suffer from thermal instability. Here, the authors realize a dielectric-free, compact metallic resonator with strong Purcell enhancement, enabling stable room-temperature maser action.

title: Efficient perovskite/Cu(In,Ga)Se<sub>2</sub> tandem solar cells with a composite intermediate recombination layer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67350-yChallenges remain in optimizing efficiency and stability of monolithic perovskite/Cu(In,Ga)Se2 (CIGS) tandem solar cells. Here, authors develop a composite-structured intermediate recombination layer and achieve maximum efficiency of 28.04% and 30.71% for 0.51 cm2 and 0.15 cm2 cells, respectively.

title: Reading the immune clock: a machine learning model predicts mouse immune age from cellular patterns
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67393-1The immune system undergoes significant changes with age. However, protein level characterization of these age-associated changes is limited. Here, the authors develop a machine learning (ML) model to predict changes in immune cell composition across different age stages based on CyTOF data on mouse CD45+ spleen cells and test the reliability of the ML model in predicting biological age using an obese mouse model, supporting the applicability of this tool to identify disease-related immune senescence.’

title: Ubiquitination by HRD1 is essential for TLR3 trafficking and its innate immune signaling
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67219-0E3 ubiquitin ligase HRD1, a core component of the ER-associated degradation (ERAD) pathway, is essential for the TLR3-mediated innate immune response. HRD1 catalyzes polyubiquitination of TLR3 at lysine 813, which promotes its trafficking to endolysosomes and enables its proteolytic cleavage and functional activation.

title: Forest-savanna stability in India under human interventions and changing climate

title: Morphodynamics of Bedrock Rivers
summary:
Landscapes are shaped by the interaction of tectonics, climate, and rock erosion dynamics. Active incision in bedrock rivers sets the pace of landscape evolution because river incision cuts deep valleys and canyons into bedrock, transporting that material to the sea. This unburdens Earth's surface, allowing uplift of majestic mountain peaks in tectonically active settings. Bedrock-bound rivers, where the banks and bed are mostly bedrock, are hard points in the landscape that set the upstream base level of drainage basins and that must be vertically incised to lower landscape elevation and balance erosion against tectonic uplift. There are four distinct bedrock-bound channel morphologies that do not occur in alluvial channels—constriction-pool-widenings, rapids, overfalls, and waterfalls—each of which has a distinct flow structure. Our ability to predict bedrock-bound channel morphodynamics is nascent, but the discovery of mechanistic lateral bedrock erosion models, coupled with existing vertical incision models, allow prediction of bedrock river geometry and adjustments due to changes in water flux, sediment supply, and regional uplift.
  • ▪  Coupled lateral and vertical erosion models reveal that the geometry of bedrock rivers is dominantly controlled by sediment supply, not discharge.
  • ▪  Coupling observations of nonuniform flow structures and erosion models confirm that bedrock-bound channels are loci of intense erosion along a river's profile.
  • ▪  Prediction of the 3D shape of bedrock-bound rivers is possible by combining models for flow, sediment transport, and bedrock erosion.
  • ▪  Morphodynamic predictions are limited by poor understanding of nonuniform flow structures, flow resistance, and sediment transport in bedrock-bound channels.
source: Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences: Most Recent Articles

summary: Nature, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03965-xJust a year after the first AI-designed antibody was made, scientists say clinical trials are on the horizon.

title: What we eat is making us obese and sick — but science shows solutions are within reach
summary: Nature, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03977-7An ambitious book challenges long-held assumptions on diet and nutrition and exposes gaps in public-health guidance.

title: Food will be more affordable — if we double funds for agriculture research now
summary: Nature, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03970-0A global drop in public and private investment in agricultural science in the past four decades is partly to blame for high food prices, an analysis reveals.

title: Author Correction: Degree of simulated suppression of Atlantic tropical cyclones modulated by flavour of El Niño
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01885-zAuthor Correction: Degree of simulated suppression of Atlantic tropical cyclones modulated by flavour of El Niño

title: Southern Ocean net primary production influenced by seismically modulated hydrothermal iron
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01862-6Earthquakes influence the amount of hydrothermal iron entering the ocean over the Australian Antarctic Ridge, which can support phytoplankton blooms by relieving surface iron limitation, according to observations combined with surface particle tracking.

title: Lessons from niche-specific fitness of Staphylococcus aureus at the wound edge
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67164-yChronic diabetic wounds create unique microenvironments that Staphylococcus aureus’s survival and adaptability, underscoring the need to study bacterial fitness and develop wound-targeted therapies to disrupt its persistence.

title: Implementing N-terminomics and machine learning to probe Nt-arginylation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66883-6Cataloguing Nt-arginylated proteins is prone to false positives. Here, the authors use MS-based fine-tuned LLM models with molecular proxies-physically identical yet known false positives-to discriminate true sites. They further track the modifications over time using prediction-based targeted MS.

title: Spectroscopic insights into the near-earth didymos-dimorphos binary system following the double asteroid redirection test (DART) mission impact
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67242-1Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART) mission impacted Dimorphos to test asteroid deflection. Here, the authors show that post-impact spectra largely match pre-impact properties, with only subtle variations probably linked to mutual events and to the evolution of the ejecta dust.

title: Biguanide-functionalized peptide mimics effectively combat drug-resistant ESKAPE pathogens and meningitis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67044-5ESKAPE pathogens-induced meningitis threatens human health due to antimicrobial resistance and low permeability of blood-brain barrier (BBB). Here, the authors report that biguanide-functionalized poly(2-oxazoline) exhibits potent activity against drug-resistant ESKAPE pathogens and effectively penetrates the BBB, providing a promising strategy for combating ESKAPE pathogens and meningitis.

title: Reactant-dependent volcano trends in Pt-catalyzed cycloalkane dehydrogenation: orbital hybridization-guided design of active sites
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66782-wCatalyst design is typically tailored to individual reactions because universal descriptors connecting molecular structure to ideal active-site configurations are lacking. Here, the authors reveal a reactant-dependent volcano trend in Pt-catalyzed cycloalkane dehydrogenation, dictated by the Pt–Pt coordination number.

title: Extremely cold ocean temperatures in iron formation brine pools of snowball Earth
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67155-zAnomalous iron isotopes of banded iron formation deposited during the severe global glaciation ~700 million years ago known as “Snowball Earth” represent a signature of the coldest ocean temperature ever measured on record.

title: The rise and global spread of IMP carbapenemases (1996-2023): a genomic epidemiology study
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66874-7Carbapenemase blaIMP genes between 1996-2023 were analysed across 4,556 genomes, revealing variant-specific epidemiologies and endemicities. Horizontal gene transfer enabled broad inter-species transmission, along with expansion of successful clones.

title: Mechanism of RPA phosphocode priming and tuning by CDK1/WEE1 signaling circuit
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66794-6RPA is an essential ssDNA binding protein. Here, authors uncover a phosphosite on RPA70 and show that the RPA70 and RPA32 subunits cooperate through a phosphocode to reconfigure RPA domains. This suggests a common mode of reciprocal regulation of RPA and kinases during G2/M phase of cell cycle.

title: Antarctic Bottom Water in a changing climate
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00750-2Antarctic Bottom Water (AABW) sinks near Antarctica and fills the deep ocean. This Review discusses how AABW is formed, past changes to its properties and transport, and projects future changes in AABW and the deep overturning circulation.

title: Ecosystem carbon and nitrogen recovery in restored coastal wetlands
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03036-zPlant biomass carbon in restored wetlands requires about 20 years to reach natural levels while soil carbon and nitrogen stocks need 40 years to recover, suggests a meta-analysis of 110 salt marsh and 190 mangrove sites under various restoration types.

title: Trait-based predictions of ecosystem properties in coastal forests
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03065-8Plant traits, particularly height and basal diameter, are strong predictors of ecosystem property variations in coastal forests, based on a meta-analysis of global 396 data points and field data in eastern China

title: Limited capability of current satellite solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence reconstructions to capture stomatal responses to environmental stresses
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03035-0Remotely sensed solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence overestimates gross primary productivity under dry conditions due to the decoupling between stomatal responses and the fluorescence emission yield, as revealed by data from 103 eddy covariance towers and satellite thermal images.

title: Projections of global road risk exposed to landslides under climate change
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03073-8Under high-emission scenarios, a projection of ~30.6% greater global landslide risk to roads is likely by 2100, with wealthier countries facing disproportionately elevated risk, according to findings from coupled model intercomparison project phase 6 and machine learning models

title: Memory and jamming in fault zone sediments
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02952-4Creep and earthquakes produce distinct microstructural fabrics, representing a form of material memory that can be created and erased through the seismic cycle, according to X-ray microtomography of sediments within the San Andreas fault zone.

title: Enhanced weather persistence due to amplified Arctic warming
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03050-1Weather persistence, in terms of duration of surface-air temperature anomalies across all weather types and seasons in Northern Hemisphere mid-latitudes, has increased in recent decades due to Arctic temperature amplification, according to a study analysing reanalysis data.

title: Home-field advantage: how local research leads to new discoveries
summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03980-yBy studying caves near his home in Johannesburg, South Africa, geologist Tebogo Makhubela ventures into places people have never been before.

summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03844-5Luciano Moreira is part of Nature’s 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.

summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03976-8From flaming raisins to robots and rockets, the institution’s Christmas Lectures have educated and entertained for two centuries.

summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03847-2KJ Muldoon is part of Nature’s 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.

summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03979-5Students and a financial planner give their advice on budgeting, saving and investing during doctoral studies.

summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03904-wThe German government has committed half a billion euros for research on long COVID and other post-infection syndromes.

title: The visionary physicist who gave us a new way to view the cosmos
summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03840-9Tony Tyson is part of Nature’s 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.

summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03843-6Mengran Du is part of Nature’s 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.

summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03839-2Achal Agrawal is part of Nature’s 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.

title: This scientist found a new trick of the immune system by digging through cellular rubbish
summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03846-3Yifat Merbl is part of Nature’s 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.

title: How to get science back into policymaking
summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03978-6Misunderstanding and hubris have broken public trust in governments’ use of science, but it can be restored.

title: The first global pandemic treaty — and the woman who made it happen
summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03841-8Precious Matsoso is part of Nature’s 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.

title: Five years of COVID vaccines: how a breakthrough created a public-heath crisis
summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03992-8Physician and science communicator Kristen Panthagani talks about why public trust in vaccines has fallen since the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Refining the crust
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01865-3Heat-producing elements like uranium and thorium are depleted in the lower crust. The geochemistry of crustal rocks suggests ultrahigh melting temperatures are needed to produce this depletion and may also help stabilize the crust.

title: Mesoamerican beliefs sculpted in jadeite
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01852-8Jadeite is a green jade mineral that forms in unique geological environments. Mayra Manrique-Ortega and colleagues explain its archaeological importance for pre-Columbian Mesoamerican civilizations.

title: Climate change fuels the Great Atlantic Sargassum Belt
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01871-5Our oceans are changing rapidly, with climate-driven shifts in circulation and nutrient cycles reshaping marine ecosystems in profound ways. One of the most visible and disruptive outcomes is the explosive growth of Sargassum — a floating brown alga that has, since 2011, formed vast rafts stretching thousands of kilometres across the Atlantic Ocean. Once largely confined to the Sargasso Sea, where it provides habitat for fish, turtles, and eels, Sargassum now inundates coastlines from West Africa to the Caribbean Islands and Florida. In a new report in Nature Geoscience, Jung et al.1 have identified the source of nutrients fueling Sargassum blooms, which are increasing as a result of climate change.

title: Tightening the Sargassum belt
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01886-yA belt of seaweed has formed across the tropical Atlantic nearly every year since 2011, despite reduction in its extent elsewhere. The causes of this growth are now coming into clearer focus.

title: Neglecting vertical transport leads to underestimated soil carbon dynamics
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01846-6A reassessment of soil radiocarbon profiles, which shows a strong influence of vertical transport processes, suggests that soil organic carbon is similarly responsive to environmental changes regardless of depth.

title: Author Correction: Inhibition of protein glycosylation is a novel pro-angiogenic strategy that acts via activation of stress pathways
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67407-yAuthor Correction: Inhibition of protein glycosylation is a novel pro-angiogenic strategy that acts via activation of stress pathways

title: Publisher Correction: Light patterning semiconductor nanoparticles by modulating surface charges
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66660-5Publisher Correction: Light patterning semiconductor nanoparticles by modulating surface charges

title: In-situ grafting of cobalt phthalocyanine on gas diffusion electrodes enables ampere-level CO<sub>2</sub> reduction
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66808-3The development of carbon dioxide reduction catalysts at industrial current densities remains challenging. Here, the authors demonstrate that in situ electro-polymerization of cobalt phthalocyanine on a gas diffusion electrode achieves high carbon monoxide selectivity at high current densities.

title: Widespread Fab-arm exchange affects all endogenous serum IgG4
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67105-9Among the antibody subclasses, IgG4 is unique in its capability to fragment-antigen-binding (Fab)-arm exchange, a process that renders IgG4 bispecific for antigen binding. Here authors analyse serum IgG4 clonal repertoires of healthy human donors to show that Fab-arm exchange is widespread and affects all IgG4 clones.

title: Dissipative quadratic soliton in the cascaded nonlinearity limit
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67195-5In this work, the authors demonstrate nonlinearity-engineered dissipative quadratic solitons (DQS) for the first time. Moreover, they achieve an in-situ sign reversal of the effective nonlinearity, enabling a transition from bright DQS to platicon generation without requiring any dispersion engineering.

title: Continuous flow photosynthesis of methanol from methane by plasmonic charge accumulation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67051-6The combination of plasmon-mediated electron enrichment and a continuous-flow reactor overcomes key challenges in selective methane oxidation, achieving a methanol production rate of over 6.5 mmol·g-1·h-1 with the selectivity of 100% and sustained stability over 100 h under ambient pressure.

title: Inflammation-specific DNA origami nanodevice for delivery of siRNAs to treat ulcerative colitis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67183-9Optimal siRNA assembly, delivery, and release are key to ulcerative colitis treatment. Here the authors develop an inflammation-specific DNA origami nanodevice for targeted delivery of siRNAs to the intestine and selective exposure of siRNAs at inflamed sites, achieving effective therapy.

title: Metabolic support protects mucosa from ferroptosis in radiation-induced mucositis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67214-5Here the authors show that radiation triggers oral mucositis via ferroptosis in basal epithelial cells, while fibroblasts provide early protection by supplying polyamines that inhibit this cell death pathway.

title: Author Correction: Marsh restoration in front of seawalls is an economically justified nature-based solution for coastal protection
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03061-yAuthor Correction: Marsh restoration in front of seawalls is an economically justified nature-based solution for coastal protection

title: Dual function of root systems in balancing soil water flow behavior
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03062-xRoot systems under loam soil conditions promote both preferential flow and soil matrix flow behavior, according to X-ray computed microtomography, dye-tracing experiments, and 3-dimensional soil-water flow modelling software at the mixed forest stands, eastern China.

title: The 2025 Blatten disaster in the Swiss Alps followed exceptional warming and highlights the vulnerability of people and heritage in glaciated landscapes
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02994-8On 28 May 2025, twenty million cubic metres of rock and ice buried the medieval village of Blatten and nearby settlements in the Swiss Lötschen valley. In the wake of the warmest decade since at least 742 CE, the disaster underlines the impact of climate warming on people and heritage.

title: Declining number of northern hemisphere land-surface frozen days under global warming and thinner snowpacks
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03059-6Rising air temperatures and thinning snowpacks result in a significantly declining number of frozen days per year across 70% of northern hemisphere ecoregions, according to analysis of satellite-based freeze-thaw data.

title: Reservoir artificial flood discharge is a critical driver for the compositional and functional shifts of dissolved organic matter in river mouth
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02920-yDuring water release, rapid discharge of upper-layer water from Xiaolangdi Reservoir increased bio-labile dissolved organic matter at the Yellow River mouth, while sediment flushing resuspended bottom sediments and enhanced aromatic components, as shown by optical spectroscopy and isotope analysis.

title: Onset of summer aridification and the decline of Homo floresiensis at Liang Bua 61,000 years ago
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02961-3Severe summer aridification caused freshwater scarcity and the decline of Homo floresiensis and its prey at Liang Bua 61,000 years ago, as revealed by a rainfall record based on speleothem geochemical data from the island of Flores, Indonesia.

title: Concise synthesis of chiral tricyclic γ-lactams via synergistic isothiourea/Ir catalyzed asymmetric [3 + 2] annulation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67390-4Accessing tricyclic frameworks with multiple contiguous stereocenters remains challenging. Here, the authors report a isothiourea/Ir-catalyzed [3 + 2] annulation providing trans-fused tricyclic γ-lactams with three contiguous tertiary stereocenters.

title: CASSIA: a multi-agent large language model for automated and interpretable cell annotation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67084-xAssigning cell types in single-cell RNA-seq is essential yet challenging, as it requires expertise, time, and is often subjective. Here, the authors present CASSIA, a multi-agent AI system that provides automated, interpretable, and quality-controlled annotations with high accuracy.

title: Molecular competition induced Janus hydrogel bioelectronic interface for electroceutical modulation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67143-3Janus hydrogel bioelectronic interfaces are challenged by complex fabrication, poor tunability of asymmetric properties and weak interlayer bonding strength. Here, the authors create a Janus hydrogel with dual structural and compositional gradients in one step via molecular competition induction mechanism.

title: EP300 deficiency leads to chronic replication stress mediated by defective replication fork protection
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67171-zLoss-of-function mutations in EP300/KAT3B and CBP/KAT3A have been implicated in the pathogenesis of cancer. Here, the authors reveal that the EP300 protein has a role in mediating replication fork protection at sites of replication stalling and show that EP300-mutated cells recapitulate features of BRCA-deficient cancers.

title: Retro-inversion imparts antimycobacterial specificity to host defense peptides
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67162-0In this work, authors show that retro-inversion of host-defense peptides markedly improves their antitubercular potency and selectivity, highlighting the potential of this simple chemical modification to advance the design of novel antimycobacterial biotherapeutics.

title: Multichannel, ultra-wideband Rydberg electrometry with an optical frequency comb
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64439-2Rydberg atoms have the potential to serve as broadband receivers but require lasers with > 100 GHz scan ranges to observe multiple states. We bridge this major gap with an optical frequency comb for rapid preparation of over 7 Rydberg states.

title: Carboxymethylcytosine is a natural base modification and a handle for bacteriophage DNA hypermodification
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66999-9DNA in many bacteriophages contains unusual chemical modifications. Here, the authors discover that carboxymethylcytosine is a natural DNA base and reveal its role as an intermediate enabling further DNA hypermodification.

title: Global floating algae blooms are expanding
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66822-5While phytoplankton are well studied and understood at the global scale, floating macroalgae are not. This study presents a comprehensive picture of the global distributions of floating macroalgae and phytoplankton surface scums, both showing expanding trends from 2003 to 2022.

title: Nutrient limitation regimes control sunlight-stimulated chlorophyll fluorescence in the South Atlantic Ocean
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 07 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03067-6Passive chlorophyll fluorescence is sensitive to phytoplankton nutrient limitation, according to in-situ observations from the South Atlantic Ocean.

title: Precious metal enrichment during impacts on the Moon
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03046-xLunar impact melt sheets may contain platinum group element enrichments consistent with sulfide-silicate segregation, according to geochemical and petrographic observations of lunar impact breccia meteorite samples.

title: Focused groundwater recharge is controlled by landscape and climate
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03063-wConcentrated water infiltration was detected in 46% of Australian groundwater bores across arid and wet climates, suggesting that conventional diffuse-only recharge estimates may significantly underestimate total recharge, according to Tritium data from more than 1,700 samples.

title: Causes and consequences of Arctic amplification elucidated by coordinated multimodel experiments
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03052-zThe Polar Amplification Model Intercomparison Project reveals robust jet stream and storm track responses to Arctic sea-ice loss that are separable from internal variability, and the model diversity provides pathways to constrain the real-world response

title: Biodiversity regulates the asymmetric influence of forest cover gain and loss on land surface temperature
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03048-9Biodiversity intensifies the uneven cooling and warming effects of forest gain and loss on land surface temperature by modulating climate variability and enhancing soil carbon processes, as revealed by satellite, climate, soil, topography, and vegetation data.

title: Worldwide trends in metabolic syndrome from 2000 to 2023: a systematic review and modelling analysis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67268-5The global burden of Metabolic syndrome is incompletely characterized. Here the authors report a systematic review and modelling study showing that global metabolic syndrome prevalence doubled from 2000 to 2023, now affecting 1.54 billion adults (31.0% of women, 25.7% of men), with higher rates in women, urban areas, and high-income countries, with disparities across regions.

title: SlingBAG: point cloud-based iterative algorithm for large-scale 3D photoacoustic imaging
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66855-wResearchers present SlingBAG, an iterative reconstruction algorithm for large-scale 3D photoacoustic imaging. It uses an adaptive point cloud model to achieve high-quality imaging from sparse data, notably cutting cost in both memory and time.

title: A next-generation dual guide CRISPR system for genetic interaction library screening
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67256-9Large-scale combinatorial perturbation screens are important to identify genetic interactions and synthetic lethal gene pairs. Here, Burgold et al. present a next-generation dual guide system that allows library-scale screening across hundreds of thousands of genetic interactions.

title: Subsurface engineering for directional-selective CO₂-to-ethanol electrocatalysis at industrial-level
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67176-8Precisely controlling the configuration of oxygen-binding intermediates is crucial for selective CO2-to-ethanol electroreduction. Here, the authors present a subsurface Co-doped CuS catalyst, which transforms key intermediates via surface-O bonds to achieve directional selectivity for ethanol.

title: A light-induced microprotein triggers regulated intramembrane proteolysis to promote photo-sensing in a pathogenic bacterium
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66862-xLight represses biofilm formation and production of virulence factors in the pathogenic bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Here, Manias et al. identify a periplasmic microprotein that regulates this process by activating the degradation of a component of the light-sensing pathway.

title: CMIP6 models cannot capture long-term forced changes in the tropical Pacific sea surface temperature gradient
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66839-wClimate models cannot match long-term observed changes in the tropical Pacific zonal sea surface temperature gradient, implying that model responses to increasing radiative forcing from atmospheric greenhouse gases are diverging from the real world.

title: Arraying faceted manganese oxides for selective ethylene electro-oxidation to ethylene glycol in aqueous electrolytes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66973-5The electrooxidation of ethylene to ethylene glycol (EG) offers a sustainable pathway for chemical manufacturing, but demands selective non-precious-metal electrocatalysts. Here, the authors report a class of (111)-rich Mn2O3 nanoarray electrode, which achieves a high selectivity of 52.6% for for ethylene-to-EG conversion in aqueous electrolytes.

title: Anti-swelling and self-activating artificial proteoglycan assemblies as cartilaginous implant for post-microfracture healing
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67035-6The insufficient structure and biofunction of cartilaginous implant impede cartilage regeneration. Here, the authors develop anti-swelling and self-activating artificial proteoglycan assemblies for post-microfracture healing by downregulate calcium signaling pathway and reducing ossification.

title: Chiral phonons in polar LiNbO<sub>3</sub>
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66911-5The authors demonstrate the existence of chiral phonons in a non-chiral ferroelectric material, opening the possibility for phonon chirality control through ferroic switching of the electric polarization.

title: Bone homeostasis regulation by in vivo generation of osteoclast-derived apoptotic bodies using targeted self-assembly
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66791-9Triggering the natural repair processes in the body has huge potential in tissue regeneration. Here, the authors develop a bone-targeted nanoparticle that selectively eliminates osteoclasts and generates pro-regenerative apoptotic bodies, restoring bone density and treating osteoporosis.

title: Lipid dependence of connexin-32 gap junction channel conformations
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67004-zGap junction channels formed by Cx32 enable intercellular communication, and their disruption causes CMT1X disease. Here, authors use cryo-EM and molecular dynamics simulations to show how specific lipids and sterols may directly control Cx32 channel gating

title: Host switching mutations in H5N1 influenza hemagglutinin suppress site-specific activation dynamics
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66926-yKephart et al. use biophysical approaches to probe changes in H5N1 influenza hemagglutinin dynamic behavior resulting from transmission-adaptation mutations. Subtype-specific patterns of activation dynamics are revealed that indicate underlying physical constraints on HA adaptation.

title: Advancing aerogel recyclability through polyhexahydrotriazine reactivity
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67059-yThe sustainable use of organic aerogels is limited by their non-recyclability owing to the covalently-crosslinked networks that constitute their structures. Here, the authors report on the dynamic chemistry of hexahydrotriazine units to develop recyclable aerogels.

title: Sustainable alkane production from waste fatty acids via electrochemically coupled decarboxylation and hydrogenation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66858-7The defossilization platform offers a competitive approach to produce sustainable hydrocarbon fuels directly from biomass-derived feedstocks. Here, the authors report an integrated electrochemical strategy for converting renewable fatty acids into liquid alkanes under mild and scalable conditions.

title: Taming harmful bursts and heat flux in high-confinement tokamak plasmas
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67080-1Tokamak walls suffer erosion from steady and bursty heat loads. Here, the authors demonstrate that optimizing 3D magnetic field and cooling gas injection can tame destructive plasma bursts while enabling cooler, safer exhaust conditions.

title: Electron-conductive binder for silicon negative electrode enabling low-pressure all-solid-state batteries
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66851-0Silicon negative electrode in all-solid-state batteries can lose electrical contact at low stack pressure, reducing performance. Here, the authors introduce a conductive, water-processable polymer binder that preserves contact and supports stable operation at low stack pressure.

summary: Science, Volume 390, Issue 6777, December 2025.

authors: Darío Gil and Kathryn A. Moler
summary: Science, Volume 390, Issue 6777, Page 965-965, December 2025.

authors: Ruocheng Hu, Shuangqi Liu, Lingyun Xiao, Ziyun Zhu, Yuehan Dou, Shen Zhang, Xiaotong Ren, Fangyuan Hua, and Zhi Lu

authors: Michael Funk, and Jelena Stajic, Di Jiang, Phil Szuromi, Michael A. Funk, Madeleine Seale, Annalisa VanHook, Marc S. Lavine, Christiane P. Koch, Caroline Ash, Ekeoma Uzogara, Christiana N. Fogg, and Molly Ogle
summary: Science, Volume 390, Issue 6777, Page 1012-1014, December 2025.

title: Probabilistic greedy algorithm solver using magnetic tunneling junctions for traveling salesman problem
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66864-9Solving a task of optimal route search may be challenging for conventional algorithms. Here, authors use tunable random signals from magnetic tunnel junctions to improve a probabilistic greedy Traveling Salesman Problem solver to better balance exploration and efficiency, and make it applicable for larger problems.

title: Water sources and land capacitor effects stimulate observed summer Arctic moistening and warming
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 03 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03000-xTrends in boreal summer large scale circulation have been a key factor in the moistening of the Arctic over recent decades, according to analyses of Earth system model simulations.

title: Sustained supershear rupture during the 2025 Mandalay, Myanmar earthquake
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 02 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02927-5The Mw 7.7 2025 Mandalay earthquake displayed initial bilateral sub-shear rupture which then transitioned into sustained super-shear in the southward propagation direction, according to a combination of geodetic, finite fault inversion, back-projection and dynamic rupture analyses

title: Urbanization is projected to increase local surface temperature by 2100
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 02 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02947-1By 2100, urbanization contributes an average local warming of 0.1 degree centigrade, and up to 16 percent of urban areas experience extreme warming exceeding 1 degree centigrade, according to an analysis that combines climate model projections and a dynamic regression model.

title: Photogrammetry and analogue experiments in 3D-printed mold applied to the 2022-2023 lava emplacement at Lascar Volcano in Chile
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 02 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03011-8The Lascar volcano’s crater floor was lifted due to lava extrusion, followed by a funnel-shaped structure that cooled and solidified due to magma withdrawal, providing constraints on the geometry of underlying volcanic conduit, according to photogrammetry and analogue experiments in 3D-printed mold.

title: A hydrologically informed agricultural land use intensity index for assessing ecological impacts on streams and rivers
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 02 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02933-7Pesticide pressure has the strongest association with ecological status in Germany particularly in low-order streams and the central highlands, as revealed by a new land use intensity index explicitly considering multiple hydrological information.

title: ENSO amplifies global vegetation resilience variability in a changing climate
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66987-zENSO shapes global vegetation resilience by driving both synchronization and climate-mediated impacts. This study reveals its influence on over half of the global vegetated area resilience and identifies future hotspots of ecosystem vulnerability.

title: Ecological shift in a remote alpine lake in inland Asia induced by European air pollutants
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03060-zExtremely remote alpine lakes may experience ecological shifts due to hemispheric-scale anthropogenic influences, according to diatom ecological analysis of Shuanghu Lake in the Altai Mountains of inland Asia.

title: Timing of a future glaciation in view of anthropogenic climate change
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02867-0Historical emissions alone are unlikely to delay glacial inception, which is predicted to occur around 50,000 years from now, but doubling current emissions through continued human activities could delay it by another 50,000 years, according to analysis of the Earth system model simulations for the next 200,000 years.

title: Monsoon winds create an expressway for migratory shorebirds on the East Asia-Australasian Flyway
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03049-8Migratory shorebirds can leverage monsoon winds to have higher speeds along the East Asia-Australasian Flyway, reveals an analysis of satellite tracking of three bird species and monsoon indexes.

title: Persistent rupture segmentation of the Main Marmara Fault
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03007-4The magnitudes and epicentral locations of earthquakes along the Main Marmara Fault, Türkiye, are governed by fault geometry, such as fault bends, and by rheological barriers like thick sedimentary sequences, according to simulations of 10,000 years of the seismic cycle.

title: Hydrothermal weakening and slope instability at Vulcano (Italy) analyzed using drones and in-situ strength measurements
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03014-5At La Fossa cone, Vulcano, Italy, alteration intensity, when categorized by color, correlates with rock weakening and past mass wasting events, as determined by drone mapping and in-situ strength surveys.

title: Environmental levels of indole-3-acetic acid enhance the uptake and translocation of polyfluoroalkyl ether sulfonates in wheat
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 03 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03022-5Commonly used auxin herbicides at environmentally relevant concentrations promoted the absorption and translocation of chlorinated polyfluoroalkyl sulfonate in wheat, indicating ecological risk, according to plant exposure experiments.

title: Fast estimation of landslide blocks’ volume from seismic noise measurements
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 03 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02999-3The volume of landslide rock blocks can be estimated from seismic noise measurements identifying their vibration signal, knowing the blocks’ area, and using an adequate abacus.

title: Irrigation cooling effect reduced by water-saving practices
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 03 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03030-5Water-saving irrigation weakens daytime cooling and enhances nighttime cooling across China; satellite and surface energy balance analyses (2001–2020) link this to reduced soil evaporation, increased sensible heat, and altered land–atmosphere interactions.

title: Author Correction: Activity of caspase-8 determines plasticity between cell death pathways
summary: Nature, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09980-2Author Correction: Activity of caspase-8 determines plasticity between cell death pathways

title: Aluminium is crucial to vaccines — and safe. Why are US advisers debating it?
summary: Nature, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03955-zRFK Jr’s vaccine advisory panel will be discussing the inclusion of adjuvants in childhood vaccinations this week. Here’s what’s at stake.

title: Hydrotrope-enabled high concentration aqueous electrolytes for reversible and sustainable iron metal anodes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65160-wIron metal batteries are hindered by poor reversibility and hydrogen evolution. Here, authors introduce a urea-based hydrotrope to create a high-concentration ferrous sulfate electrolyte, enabling stable, dendrite-free cycling and advancing cost-effective, sustainable energy storage.

title: Benchmarking all-atom biomolecular structure prediction with FoldBench
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67127-3Accurate all-atom structure prediction is essential for biology and medicine, yet systematic benchmarks remain limited. Here, authors introduce FoldBench, a dataset of 1,522 targets across nine tasks, mapping strengths and challenges across diverse biomolecular interactions.

summary: Publication date: Available online 3 December 2025Source: Earth-Science ReviewsAuthor(s): Pavel G. Talalay, Nan Zhang, Xiaopeng Fan, Yazhou Li, Da Gong, Bing Li

title: Dramatic decline of Sargassum in the north Sargasso Sea since 2015
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01863-5Sargassum biomass in the north Sargasso Sea declined drastically since 2015, co-occurring with related reductions in the northwest Gulf of Mexico and an expansion of the Great Atlantic Sargassum Belt, according to in situ and satellite observations.

title: The rise of free oxygen may have initiated on marine mud
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01867-1The oxygenation of Earth’s atmosphere ~2.45–2.30 billion years ago may have initiated in the oxidized bottom waters of marine shelves, according to a synthesis of thallium and nitrogen isotopes and cyanobacteria phylogenetic records.

title: Multiphase aqueous soggy sand electrolyte for zinc metal batteries applications at elevated temperatures
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67020-zAqueous zinc metal batteries often face performance decay under thermal environments, originating from side reactions caused by aqueous electrolytes. Here, authors report an organic-inorganic-H2O multiphase aqueous soggy-sand electrolyte that reconstructs hydrogen-bond networks, eliminates parasitic reactions, and promotes uniform Zn deposition at elevated temperature (140 oC).

title: Rift linkage and inheritance determine collisional mountain belt evolution
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66695-8Using 3D numerical models, this research shows how pre-existing rift basin structures influence the shape and growth of mountain belts, offering a way to link surface topography with deep Earth processes in regions like the Pyrenees and Caucasus.
